author: Ashley L.

description: This restaurant serves tasty Indian food, but I find it a bit expensive for what you get. The chicken tikka masala sauce is great, but the chicken pieces is sometimes dry. The somosas are outstanding.
author: Amanda F.

description: Indian Oven has very tasty food!  My favorite is the sag paneer, and the korma is great too.  One of the better Indian restaurants I've been to in SF.
author: Carrie P.

description:
Either my expectations have been raised, prices are higher, portions are smaller, or a combination of all the above. Indian Oven just wasn't as good as I remembered it.

My first time here, years ago, was awesome. I think it was my first proper Indian meal out, and I was blown away by the quality and the experience. Never forget that flaming kitchen just a few feet away. Goodness was being cooked.

Back for a second round, and while the Chicken Tikka Masala was good, it was heavy, expensive and there just wasn't much of it. I definitely had higher expectations.

The chai tea offered while waiting was a nice touch, and remembering a meal this well years later is worth at least a third star, but don't think I'll be back again.
author: Jason B.

description:
Disappointing. Very bland. The tandoori chicken tasted like fake crab. The delivery guy took 2 hours. The garlic naan was ok. The chicken saagwala was probably the best of the items I ordered, but it was still watery and had a sweet limey taste. 

Needless to say, I won't be ordering from here again. Maybe there are some other items on the menu worth investigating, but I'll let you figure that one out without me.
author: Ashley B.

description: We live in the neighborhood and absolutely love this place. I like it a whole lot better than most other Indian foods in the city. What puts them over the top is the sampler for two at a reasonable price. It's all my favorite dishes and it's like getting items two for free. Love it and recommend it to everyone. I also enjoy the beautiful paintings on the walls.
author: Alex A.

description: This is my favorite Indian place in SF. They have a varied menu with lots of traditional Indian dishes, and the prices are very reasonable. It's great if you are a vegetarian, and the staff are quite friendly.
author: Tbone M.

description: Best Indian food outside of the Tenderloin! Really nice atmosphere and friendly service -- great for a date. They even offer delicious chai tea while you wait for takeout.
author: Liz A.

description:
I had a pretty bad experience here.  Only one other table was occupied  when we showed up on a Saturday afternoon for a late lunch, so to say they weren't too busy is a strong understatement.  Things started off pretty rough: Multiple water glasses at our table were dirty.  Even one of the replacements was dirty but we ended up just cutting our losses to avoid entering an infinite loop.

The appetizers/sauces were actually really good but everything went downhill from there.  Service was nonexistent, which was crazy considering the lack of patrons.  They got our order wrong and forgot to bring things out so many times that it created a sphincter-tightening awkwardness at our table.   Even getting our waters refilled seemed to require a Herculean effort on their part.  Service aside, the entrees were just awful.  Worst I've ever had.  Everything was watery and flavorless.  The vegetables tastes like they came out of a Jolly Green Giant Freezer bag.  The complimentary pudding provided to us maybe slightly offset the bad  service but did nothing to change the fact that the food sucked.  The new management (which I was previously unaware of) must have just shat all over this place.

Bottom line: Go somewhere else.
author: Chris P.

description:
Worst food...with worst service. We picked this place after reading review in Fodors...came out a big flop show...total waste of money n time..
.
author: Sachin M.

description: We walked in towards the last of service and were welcomed instead of turned away.  We ordered the calamari, the sea bass and the homemade cheese in cream sauce with onion nan.  Everything was cooked perfectly and the mango lassi was delicious.  I would definitely return.  One of the best Indian cuisines in the city!
author: Elizabeth C.

description: Very fresh, delicious food. The pakoras were the best I've had. They don't use old oil or over batter. All of the entrees that we shared were likewise fresh and tasty.
author: Robyn B.

description: Best Indian ever.  Bonus points for service and a great setting.  A little expensive, but well worth it.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Goat cheese nann...do i need to say anymore! This place serves north indian food...that's the creamy cheesy variety of Indian food that i love. 

Here's what you have to try (not sure about spelling): 
-Navratan Korma 
-chicken tika massala 
-saag paneer 
-mixed seafood curry 
-lamb byrani rice dish 
-fried eggplant appetizers 


and the assorted naan basket is a good choice for four people. It's a good amount of naan and they make it fresh. If you don't want the assortment, at least get the garlic...and remember, as long as everyone eats some nobody can smell your breath. 

The service was good and the glabajamens (dessert) were the best I've had because they serve them slightly warm so they're light and fluffy. I preferred this over getting them dense and cold the way they're normally served. 

enjoy.
author: Philip H.

description:
This is my go-to place for Indian food, as I used to live blocks from it--now I drive to get it!

Love the veggie korma (my #1 choice), saag, and palak paneer. The naan is yummy, and they also give yummy papadum in the beginning. I think the food is a little different from what I remember, but still good. We ordered the veggie pakoras tonight, and not as good as the last time we ordered it...still, check it out if you are around and want some yummy food.
author: Kat D.

description:
Went here several weeks ago and enjoyed it; then made plans to visit again and were surprised at a lot of negative reviews on Yelp.  Went anyway, and glad we did.  Food was great all around - tasty, just the right spice (and a notable difference between one person's "medium", another's "spicy", and a 3rd's "extra spicy" -- often these distinctions seem lost at Indian restaurants).

My only complaint was that my mattar paneer seemed a little light on the peas (they can't cost that much).  That, and the overly-soft-spoken waiters, make it 4 stars not 5.  But all in all, the I think the negative reviewers out there have it in for this place for some bizarre reason; the food is clearly not the problem!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Any good reviews on here must come from people who really don't know what Indian food is supposed to taste like. I'm from the UK and I know Indian food, believe me. I have had some of the best out there... and this place is nowhere near.

I stopped in on the way home to get some food to go. I received bland food with none of the authentic rich, spiced taste I would expect. Lousy veg biriani. Lousy channa masala with thin, watery sauce. Lousy samosa. The keema nan was the only remotely redeeming thing I ordered. Chai, average, same as everyone else's.

Also - incredibly overpriced! Won't be going again. Ever.
author: Alison S.

description: Food is not that good and service was awful. I ordered delivery and they messed up on my order. I called and let them know and asked for another plate. (I don't eat meat, it came with meat) and very long story short I didn't get my money or food until the next day. ??? Bad service. Will not go there again.
author: Chelsea G.

description: great Indian Restaurant in the Lower Haight. Give it a try if you love the cuisine.
author: Meesh R.

description: Consistently delicious food. The daal saag is not to be missed. Sunny provided great service at lunch.  Very accommodating of special requests. One of the few places than serves gulab jamun like it should be- warm.
author: Ashwini K.

description:
Big fan of the appetizers - fried goodness like samosas and pakoras. The meat is pretty good too - I've had chicken and lamb here. Overall everyone I've been here with likes it a lot.

Service is hit or miss. I hate when you ask for recommendations and the waiter just won't help out. I even narrowed it to two dishes "But what do you recommend the chicken or the lamb?" "It depends on whether you want to eat chicken or lamb" doh.

Clean and elegant for an Indian restaurant but you literally have to rub your butt against other diners' tables just to get by its so crowded.

*UPDATE* 2 more trips in the past year and I must say this place gets worse each time. Watery curry, too much salt -such a disappointment. I wouldn't come back, and I was such a fan before. Down to 3 stars and I feel that is generous.
author: Lainy C.

description:
All I have to say is Chicken Crack Korma, oh my, you have me addicted. 
The place itself is a little loud and stuffy though which is why I have knocked off a star. Otherwise it's the best Indian food in the city I think.
author: Drea L.

description: Very good! We had saag w mushroom, garlic naan, chicken tikka masala. And it was all extremely solid, tasty, clean. I recommend highly.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Stopped by for lunch yesterday afternoon and was struck by the elegance of linen, which in my experience has been an indicator of ambiance but mediocre food - outside of France.

The meal started out poorly, the Samosas were overcooked, almost burned. The lentil and chicken curry was better than average, nothing to Yelp about (hardy harr harr), but serviceable. Then I went to the restroom which mere feet (no more than 3) from the large brick oven where the food I had just consumed into my temple was prepared....

ROACHES!!!! Tens of them, in varying states of existing. There were so many dead roaches behind the door that I assumed they had recently been tenants at a roach motel or the building have been fumigated. 

I stepped over my six-legged hosts, tipped the minimum 10% and walked briskly away from Indian Oven. Don't go to this roach motel until the Health Department inspectors visit.
author: C C.

description:
I have been going to this restaurant for almost 15 years, and I felt it was one of the best Indian restaurants in the bay area (I work in the south bay, so I've been to a lot).  I have to say that my last meal there was one of the worst that I have had in a long time.  The fish was horribly cooked (almost no spice) and the quality of the fish was equally bad.  I also got the chana and it was also bland.  Judging by some of the other reviews, it seems like a lot of other people have the same opinion.  I noticed that almost all of the staff has changed, so I'm wondering if the change is quality is due to a change in ownership.

Anyways, I'm going to avoid this place for a long time.
author: Devin P.

description: Just got delivery, it's awful.  The food came cold, there was no spice at all, the meat (lamb) was horrible quality; nearly every bite was half fat.  The sauces looked like someone had spat in them.  The naan was burnt on the outside and not at all cooked on the inside.  This place used to be decent, but I highly recommend staying away.  I ordered for leftovers (50 bucks for 2 dishes and naan) - I'll be throwing it all away.  I used grubhub, so there was no personal interaction that might warrant poor service.  A truly disgusting experience.
author: W W.

description: Very tasty indian and attentive service, one of my two favorite indian places in San Franisco. I'm always partial to paneer tikka masala but I mixed it up with a different paneer dish and was quote satisfied. My party of 4 friends were similarly impressed with the variety of things they ordered.
author: Alan S.

description: Good Indian food.....and I don't like Indian food!! The things ya do for a loved one!!
author: Bob P.

description:
Way not worth the price!
The food was average.
The wait staff must have also had a bad night. It took FOREVER to get our order in, and receive our food.
The Manager was trying his hardest but there really should be no excuse for this, especially with sooo many tasty Indian Restaurants in SF.
author: M E.

description:
Just awesome. I went twice on my last trip to SF.

The goat cheese naan is out of this world.
author: Kyle M.

description: My friend and I were craving indian food and ventured to this place. The food was okay, but definitely overpriced for how much you're getting. In all honestly, I've had better chicken tikka masala. The food, however, was much better than their service. My friend and I were enjoying our conversation until they put our to-go bag on top of the table - right between us! Rude.
author: Michelle P.

description: They make u wait for the food while they cook all their takouts first. We waited for ever and the waiter seem totally hectic and unorganized for no reason...the place was half empty!
author: Gilbert L.

description:
My by and I got take out from here last night and we both agree this place rates around 3.5 stars or a B. It was a little pricey, but the portions were large. We ordered a lot of food and this is what we thought:

Tandoori Chicken - he liked is and thought it wasn't too spicy and had a nice flavor.

Mattar paneer - my favorite dish of the night - spicy yummy delicious curry flavor

Vegetable Biryani - decent but spicy, it needed something else though.
Vegetable Jelfrezi - very light and tasty

Samosas - too spicy (and I like spicy food, but it was overpowering)

Garlic naan, disappointing, too chewy. ( I woulda given it 4 stars if it weren't for the naan)

Overall, I would try this place again, but I think next time I will eat there instead of take out.
author: Molly M.

description:
Love this place! Best Indian food in SF, in my opinion!

The food is the perfect level of spicy, and not too salty, and not greasy at all! Also, the consistency of the veggie dishes is less soupy than most indian places, which rocks!

Also, check out the EXTENSIVE stuffed & different kinds of breads section! My personal faves: spinach & potato paratha.

Also, totally inexpensive for the quality and amount of food. & like most indian places, so vegan friendly.

Love it!

So good.
author: Jennifer S.

description: This place rocks. I came here to catch up with a friend on a Tuesday night. We got seats immediately and ordered chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, and garlic naan while chatting up a storm. The chicken was flavored very well, albeit a bit dry. The saag paneer was absolutely delicious, spicy, soft, and yet chewy. The naan was really good too, with the garlic not being too overwhelming, but the bread not being too salty. It was the perfect compliment to an all-around excellent meal, enhanced with great conversation. The only caveat is that this place is kind of pricey. For those three dishes, we ended up paying $19 per person after tax and tip.
author: Danny C.

description: These guys are awesome. I made an order around 9:30 on GrubHub, but couldn't pick up the phone and after calling several times, the driver went back to the restaurant with my food. I called them back right before the restaurant closed, and they re-made my food and delivered after they had closed. Oh, and the food was delicious. Tandoori chicken portion was enough for days.
author: Emre M.

description:
Way too expensive for what you get.  

The food is great but the portions are not very big.  You can get the same for less elsewhere.
author: Ben M.

description: I recently ordered extra spicy food for delivery. Although the delivery came quickly and the driver was very courteous, the food was very mild. I called the restaurant to comment, and Norman answered. He was extremely nice and accommodating and offered to remake everything. Not wanting to watet food, I declined, but he insisted that I call again for a free meal and delivery. I phoned last night and Norman kept his word.  The food was spectacular!!  Thank you, Norman, and Indian Oven!!
author: Heather H.

description:
It pains me to give 3-1 stars. It does. BUT, I simply can not justify more than this.
My friends and I were on our way to dinner in a cab, when we received a phone call that the place we were headed was a 1.5 hours wait. We had a quick discussion about what to eat, and ultimately decided to go for Indian food. Our cabby was Indian. Perfect! Surely he could recommend the absolute best; I mean, we had the IN. Right?
He was very excited about this place, so our hopes ran high. Until we got there...
We were seated and no one came to talk with us for about 10 minutes. The place was  not packed. Ok, fine. We were still excited.
The papadams came and they were tasty! As were all the dipping sauces, with the exception of the one that's taste mimicked the smell of Lemon Pledge. Ok, so perhaps our taste buds could use some refining?
We ordered 5 different entrées between the 4 of us, as well as samosas and eggplant pakora. 
The appetizers lacked flavor and were over fried. 
Our meals came out staggered and not  all in one time. 
The chicken tandoor came out first. It was dry, but worst of all it tasted JusT like gas. Ick. I tried! It had to go back. Inedible. 
Unfortunately I do not recall the other dishes, but can tell you that one of the 5 entrees ordered was pretty tasty. Lamb something or other.
The other chicken dish was hard and dry. 
The plates were heavy and filling.
The staff, though not busy, was stand offish and inattentive. 
I wound up with a super lame stomach ache for hours after that.
Well, I lived to tell, and at least did not have to pay for  the tandoori chicken.
Oh! And received 50% off a 2nd entree, courtesy of Yelp. Thanks Yelp!
author: Lisa H.

description: Terrible food and service. There was utter chaos among the staff and the place was DIRTY!! None of the dishes were worth eating even you were starving for days. I would never go there again...please avoid at all costs.
author: Naresh T.

description:
Food on my most recent visit: quite good. I've had both to-go from here as well as eaten in dozens of times over the past decade.

My experience is that food quality drops if you go (or order) later at night. It also seems that the portion sizes are larger for to-go orders.

Service on my most recent visit: annoying and overtly unfriendly. "Annoying": they interrupted conversation to ask if we were ready to order, never asked how things were, kept us waiting an unreasonable length of time (it was not all that busy) for the check. "Unfriendly": waiter acted like he didn't want to be there.

I do appreciate that the restaurant always looks clean, nice and well-kept, and has health scores/reports much less frightening than some of the other Indian places in SF.
author: Boogee Z.

description: It is more like a 3.5 star restaurant in my opinion. I used to live close by so I was a regular. The food is actually pretty solid. The saag paneer is flavorful, although I have had better paneer (it is a bit too tough). The daal fry is different than the daal I am used to, but I really liked it. It is a yellow daal and more dry than daal served in other restuarants, but I liked the flavor and the texture. Their spicy goat cheese naan is somewhat unique, and while I liked it, I don't know if it was worth the price. That's my only real complaint about this place. It is a bit on the expensive side for what it is. It obviously doesn't prevent me from coming here often, but I'm not sure if I would go out of my way to come here.
author: Vrushali P.

description: I will happily forgive griminess for great food . . . but in this case the food wasn't worth it either.  The initial impression of nice, white tablecloths, prettily-folded napkins, and beautiful Indian frescos was quickly dispelled upon sitting down, when a hint of sewer smell came upon me.  (It didn't go away, but was eventually disguised by the tandoori chicken, thankfully).  After we sat down, I noticed my white napkin had a fresh yellow smudge of curry on it, and my plate had some unpleasant sprinkle and residue, and the flower vase (holding a sadly fading rose) had an old crusty splash of red sauce on it.  Glancing up while conversing with my dinner partner, I noticed the ceiling fan blades were super grimy, as I later discovered also was the bathroom.  It was all in such contrast to the initial impression and left me with a facade-crumbling feeling.  I was holding out hope that the food would knock me out of my socks, but no.  One of the slices of cucumber on the salad platter looked like it had fallen on a dirty floor (trulyl!!).  The salad dressing cruet (tasted and looked like viscous generic bottled Italian) had crusty, oily drips down the side around the handle (taken right from the fridge - so it had been put away like that, and taken out and served again like that).  The tandoori chicken was actually really good (but truthfully, that's kind of easy).  The chicken tikka masala tasted like Campbell's cream of tomato soup, the aloo matar and dal were bland.  The rice was fine.  I can't figure this one out . . . the years of Zagat ratings and "Best of" stickers in the window.  I will try every other SF Indian place around before I come back here.
author: D J.

description: I don't know if it was an off night or what because I've been to Indian oven before and had great food. The calamari salad was unseasoned over cooked calamari dumped on top of a basic green salad  (lettuce, tomato wedges) with bottled Italian dressing on the side. What about that is Indian? The saag paneer was bland (ordered medium spicy) and ordinary. Only the okra was any good. Probably won't be going back.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Really? I don't know , was expecting better but whatever.  Let's put it this way, I have been having Indian food burps since we left, I feel bloated, and my husband is currently in the toilet. And we ate lightly. So, there you have it.  

Foodwise we ate all vegetarian too.......
author: Carlin S.

description:
Ordered take out via GrubHub after being taken here by my boyfriend previously and falling in LOVE with their Chicken Korma.

The food that arrived was no where near the caliber of what I had experienced before and I read now that it appears there has been a change of ownership.

Where to begin my rant? :D

The two garlic and onion naan were not even cooked properly. They were still doughy -- it was rubbery, like chewing gum. I ended up putting them back in the oven to finish off which brought them back to palatable.

The Lamb Biryani was barely warm by the time it arrived and pretty much sucked. The lamb was dry like overcooked chicken breast and the rice was hardly aromatic as you'd expect of a biryani.

The chicken pakora was soggy and bland. The korma was a complete disappointment - it was my favorite dish from there and so many have raved about how good it was.. "was" being the operative word. Now it's just completely unexceptional.

Between RNM closing and Indian Oven changing ownership, I'm running out of reasons to walk a little further over to the lower haight.

Mega sadface. :(
author: Lachlan M.

description: I ordered for take out. The staff was really nice and as I waited for my order they gave me some Chai Tea. It was delicious. Hot and soothing.  I ordered goat cheese Naan bread, Bhindi Bhaji Masala (okra dish) and rice with peas. I got my order in 10 minutes and everything was delicious. The okra dish was nice and flavorful and not overpowering. The rice was nice and tender. The Goat Cheese Naan was filling and well filled with goat cheese...yum! I will go back if I am in the area! Love.
author: Mel P.

description:
This place has promise - great samosas, wonderful wine selection, nice atmosphere and good location. The "lamb," however, was more beef-like than any lamb I've ever had, and the "extra spicy" was perhaps only mildly spiced, even if it was flavorful.

I might give it another shot in a few weeks, but in the meantime, I'll circle back to some of my favorites.
author: Rand F.

description:
I have ate and and ordered take-out from Indian Oven several times over the past few years, but a trip there last week was a disaster. The restaurant was busy, but we were told the wait for a table for two would be short. After about 10 minutes, we offered to order for take-out instead. The host insisted a table was coming available. After some confusion walking upstairs and then back down, we were seated.

A table seated after us got water. Us? Nope... The host came around after about 15 minutes to take our order and water finally showed up. We ordered and waited. In that time we watched one table get completely ignored for 20 minutes and leave. More chaos and confusion as waiters run around cleaning tables, but very little food makes it way out of the kitchen with just two cooks. After 45 minutes, we gave up. I told the server of the trouble, and to his credit, he said he would check on the order, but it was already after 9pm and my patience was up. He pressed for us to stay, so I tried to explain how I enjoyed their food, but this was unreasonable.

It makes me sad to have Indian Oven off my shortlist of beloved local restaurants, I understand there are busy or short-staffed nights, but then expectations need to be set or make some room to catch up. Don't keep seating tables if you're an hour behind.
author: Eric H.

description:
My girlfriend used to eat here all the time.  When she lived in San Fran.  I mean...like 3 times a week.  So since I love her, that might make me like it better.  /full disclosure

I lived in NYC.  I've been to the Jackson Heights Diner (Jackson Diner), all over Curry Hill, eaten at the famous chicken and rice stand (not sure if that even really counts as Indian) and even a few dhosa carts here and there.  I love Indian Food.  This place is up there with them.

For one, it is reasonably priced.  For another, it is quite delicious.  They make the naan from scratch (this is so important!) and it is delicious.  I think if you're new to Indian food you might be disappointed that the spices on most of their stuff isn't crazy.  I got the paneer makhata and it was subtly delicious.  Unlike most North Indian places I've been to, it doesn't beat you over the head with spices, it just gradually dissolves into delicious in your mouth.  The only reason I don't give it more stars than 4 is because they lack dhosas.  But really my rating is a 4.5.
author: Mike A.

description:
My favorite Indian place in the city.   

I haven't been there in a while so if the reviews who say the change of ownership has impacted the quality then...

My only warning is although I am a guy who likes a spicy meal, order the chicken vindaloo cooked hot at your own risk.  I think I lost several layers of skin and it took a week for the tastebuds to normalize.
author: James V.

description: Delicious traditional indian food. Great service, clean and beautiful arts. Don't forget the Chai, so tasty:)
author: Amy T.

description: This place is absolutely the worst. Service is terrible.  They got all of our orders wrong, and most of it was inedibly spicy.  Never ever ever ever going here again.  Absolutely the worst.
author: Andy J.

description:
This was the first Indian Restaurant I ever went to and Nothing compared for me for a long long time.  I recommended it to everyone!

Recently I have found the portions to be smaller though and the prices have gone up.

Its still great and I still go, but it used to be better bang for the buck.

Recently they have added home delivery.  I only live a quick walk away so i dont bother with this but its great to know its an option. 

They have the most incredible Pakoras - all big and chaotic looking versus the small balls many indian restaurants serve.  They are light and crispy and served with a choice of sauses.

They used to serve a fantastic mango chutney with them but they havent been putting it in my take out orders lately so I dont know if they still have it and I keep forgetting to ask.

Thier Chicken Korma is SO FRICKIN GOOD, I always want more.  Writing this now is making me want to go get some as we speak.

With a variety of Naan to choose from and varied rices I generaly go pretty basic but great options for those who want more diversity.  

They have a great selection of vegetarian options too - A large menu thats well organized so its not overwhelming yet still offering tons of options for those who dont yet have their favorites.  A good alcohol selection too.

Last time I went to go pick up my take out I was early and they offered me a complimentary indian chai coffee while I waited. Dont know if this is standard or if I got lucky that day but it was a nice guesture.

Its a great place to go with a group to be able to sample many of the dishes family style, great service and seating available in front and a back room too.  In thr front, if you are interested you can watch them cooking in the open kitchen!
author: Laurice G.

description:
came here after a night at danny coyle's for dinner and to absorb the evening's damage.  

he had the lamb vindaloo, which he enjoyed.  i was pleased with my seafood curry, my only wish was that it was spicy as i had requested.  i was surprised at how generous they were with the seafood; several chunks of sea bass, four prawns, and many bits of calamari.  at $14.95, i felt the portion represented the price.  the garlic naan was flavorful, but i have to agree with the other reviews stating it was on the thin side.  also it was lukewarm when brought to our table.  

2 curries, 1 naan, 1 plain basmati rice set us back $44.  the food was decent, but unlike some of the reviews i couldn't say it was the best indian.
author: Sheri N.

description:
Ok, so if you didn't already know, I'm INDIAN! So its hard for a Indian to enjoy outside Indian food..until I stepped into this restaurant. The food was Indian standard spicy, service was great, and the portions were just right! I really enjoyed the ambiance and will definitely be dinning here again! 

-Happy Eatings =)
author: Doreen C.

description:
It had been a long time since I had Indian food.  I wasn't looking to venture very far from my apartment so I decided to head over to Indian Oven. 

The interior of the restaurant is well appointed and great care was taken to develop the ambiance of the space.  

I ordered some Samosas to start.  The filling was very pleasant the the exterior dough was not too greasy.  I had hoped for a little bit more spice in the filling.  

I was really impressed with the poppadom here.  This is the first Indian restaurant I had been to where there wasn't a fine sheen of clarified butter covering the wafers.  My impression of the naan was similar.  Very well made naan -- made to order in fact and they were not greasy one bit.  

The entrees of chicken tikka masala and madras chicken did not fare so well.  From the description of the madras chicken on the menu it had the promise of a wonderland of flavor, sadly what arrived at my table was nothing more than dried out chunks of chicken in a flavorless brown sauce.  My eyes searched the restaurant for a salt shaker each time a forkful hit my lips to no avail.  Chicken tikka masala is something I typically order at Indian restaurants and I realize no two places make it the same but this was really something out of the ordinary.  Once again, dried chunks of chicken but this time the sauce was flavorful and pleasing.  So pleasing, I found myself tasting it over and over again, but not because it tasted like chicken tikka masala.  Eventually, I came to the conclusion that the sauce was a tomato bisque that had some Indian spices casually added to it. 

I wanted to like Indian Oven when I walked in the door but sadly I was left without that satisfying sensation one gets from eating Indian food full of vim and vigor.
author: Adam P.

description: WTF happened to Indian Oven? This used to be one of my favorite Indian places in the city. Their chicken tikka was legendary. But tonight it was like cumin overload with chunks of gristly chicken.  At first I thought they gave me the wrong dish.  Ditto for the lamb vindaloo. We threw away the leftovers. $75 down the drain... I hope it was just a bad night, but I don't see myself heading back any time soon.
author: Rudolph R.

description:
Oh no! Indian Oven has changed owners!  The waiter informed me that the "new" owners are actually the previous owners from about ten years ago. 
The food is completely different - and not good.  The tables are empty.  The staff is not as friendly.  I had to change my review, because this is not the same Indian Oven that was Zagat Rated for the past ten years and the one I craved on bad days as comfort food.  
 Big sad face.
author: Rebecca S.

description: I go here frequently. The service is variable, and can be either stellar or annoying. But the place has a friendly family-feeling to it, and a great vegetarian selection. My favorite dish there is the Saag Paneer. The Chana Masala is good if you can stand an onion-heavy preparation (I usually set aside the bulk of the onions). Their breads are outstanding. Friends have loved the tandoori chicken. It's never so packed as to be uncomfortable.
author: Lora K.

description: UPDATE: The manager of Indian Oven called me to apologize for the delivery guy's attitude after he read my previous review on Yelp.  I have to give major props to businesses that care about their customers.
author: Lara O.

description: It's about time I found something that rivals the awesomely delicious Indian/Pakistani restaurants I found in England. I was about to give up! This place had really fresh and flavorful food. We ordered vegetarian items. I even really liked the chutney and herb dips/spread they serve with the poppadoms. Service was friendly and casual but with a touch of formality, just like the places in England. Our waiter graciously served a free mango lassi to our 2 1/2 year old, which she was hesistant about at first but loved it after she tried it, of course. Can't wait to go back!
author: Angelica G.

description: I love their food. Third time ordering and each time I thought it was a hit. Tonight we had chicken tikka masala, chicken korma, rice and naan. I know nothing about the other food on the menu but these dishes are consistently good in my opinion. High recommend!
author: Nicole P.

description:
Good Indian food.  Samosas were outstanding.  Everything was good and not overly heavy. 

Service was good and the food came quickly.
author: I I.

description: Our irst time back at the Indian Oven in many years -  we had a terrific dinner. Several familiar dishes that were excellent: lamb vindaloo and matter paneer. The surprise this time was chicken hyderabadi masala which was absolutely delicious. Sopping up every last drop of the sauce with the onion kulcha was amazing. Service was pleasant and slow. We arrived at an empty restaurant at 6:30 and it was full by the time we left. Spotted several things we'll try next time.
author: Donald O.

description: Went in here on a Sunday night, so the place was pretty empty but that was a good thing. The Naan came in seconds (try the goat cheese/veggie filled Naan!) and the service was pretty good. The food came quickly and was delightful. I couldn't have picked a better Sunday night meal to satisfy my tummy. There was a cool tiger on the wall near the bathroom too.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Overall: B- 
Good place but not sure if I would return with so many other comparable Indian spots. However, you will not leave disappointed. 

Food: B 
Great assorted naans. The navratan korma was a little sweeter than I was expecting, accustomed to, but tasty nonetheless. Kulfi was disappointing. Good wine list though. 

Service: B 
All can I remember is that it was quick and friendly. 

Decor B 
It was rather loud and I remember the place being especially warm. 

Value: C 
There are cheaper places but the portions are big.
author: Roger H.

description: Regularly the best indian food I've had in the city, and the beer selection is good too.  I randomly had the Navertan Korma (sp?) and although the descritption it sounded strange to me, it was amazing.  Also the palak paneer is really good.
author: Bob L.

description: Pretty decent food. Did order chicken tiki masala, which was out in under 5 minutes...
author: Sam T.

description: Just ate here last night.  I thought the food was really good.  We had 2 vegetarian dishes and they were both really flavorful.  No problems with service and everything was really great.  Extra charge for rice and naan, and everything was a little on the pricey side, but overall very good.
author: Jonathan U.

description: Best And Most Authentic Indian Food I have had in the city. Great authentic atmosphere as well. Especially for the price. Ask for Paul. He will take care you.
author: Joel C.

description: I've lived in SF for nearly seven years and in my opinion, the food at Indian Oven is the best of any of the dozens of Indian restaurants I've eaten at in that time. And it is sunny and pleasant, and the service is always gracious. This is the place I would bring out-of-town visitors.
author: Geoff S.

description: Hands down, the best Indian food in the city. We have always had great experiences here and take all of our out-of-town guests here when they visit.  Don't miss the Chicken Tikka Masala or the any of the biryanis!
author: Max R.

description: Incredible Indian food. The owner threw us some complimentary ice cream at the end of the meal. Sealed the deal for me. Boom.
author: Ben P.

description:
I am disappointed to report that with the new owners or old owner returning I believe, this place is just not living up to authentic indian cuisine. It lacked the spices and authenticity of a good indian curry. I was really disappointed in the taste and the flavors. Which is unfortunate as its one block from my apt. I had the korma, which is one of my favorite dishes and it lacked the spices and flavor and the sauce was runny :(

Sadly, I will not be returning but on a positive note, their Dahl Soup is pretty tasty.
author: Kirsty E.

description:
"There's hella Indian restaurants in the lower Haight" said my dining companion, the lovely and always entertaining Debbie L.  

"There are like two." I replied, all Mr. Know It All.

Turns out she was right.  There are four.  And the one I've been to the most - India Oven, didn't even cross my mind.  What's my point, you may ask?  I'll tell you:  when I am wrong, I admit it.

So we had a Kingfisher, the saag with cheese and cauliflower, the sea bass masala, and the goat cheese naan.  Now all you Indian food purists can go on and on all day about how items 3 and 4 on that list are not "true Indian" food.  Whatever man - this is the Land of Freedom.  That stuff tasted fantastic.  And no complaints at all about the service.

Indian Oven gets 5 stars for being the tastiest Indian restaurant in SF. -1 for being the second most expensive Indian restaurant in SF.  But I'll be back anyway  ;)
author: Joe C.

description: Awesome food.  Best Indian in the city in my opinion.  Add some spice to the butter chicken, get some vindaloo, and saag paneer and you're set.  Rice pudding as a finish was nice - interesting spice to it.  Highly recommend.  And Paul our server was exceptional.
author: Eric N.

description:
For review # 308 of Indian Oven, you don't need me to go into great detail. You can easily sort reviews and get the pertinent deets. 

But this Japo thinks that Indian Oven rivals the South Bay in best of Bay Area Indian food. (no, cafe kevo does not serve indian food.) 

For best results, go with two hot single women! You know the food is decent and the company is great when you're sweating before you're finished with the samosas...and you're drenched without even having vindaloo....and you just downed two beers... and drank enough (yes drank!) enough raita to make a cow blush.

It's really 3-1/2 stars. I still smell like tika masala.
author: Kevo M.

description:
I'm over it. There are three Indian restaurants I can eat at without suffering a stomache after. Indian Oven was one of them, but I won't be back. I am completely turned off after a recent visit. The waiter slammed a little quadro of sauces and chutneys on our table, but each jar was almost empty, and it just looked like he took it off another table and gave it directly to us. 

They don't have lids or anything, so they sit there exposed all day. I know restaurants don't give each customer fresh sauce and chutney, but at least wipe the jar clean, give us clean spoons to scoop it out with, and refill the jars! It's not that hard.

Then there was the food. Nothing exciting. It was like a spicier version of the boxed Indian food at Trader Joe's. The portions were small and the prices were too high for what we ordered. I left unimpressed and hungry.
author: akimbo j.

description:
After eating here a couple of times, I then avoided it for years because I found it so unexplainably over-rated and over-priced that it pained me even to walk by.  Recently I went back for a re-visit, and found it, well, over-rated and over-priced.  At least they're consistent!

I do appreciate that they can make a spicy dish if you ask for it.  And in general, the food does not warrant avoiding (particularly when you live a mere 2 blocks away).  However, it also does not inspire one to go racing across town for it either.  Furthermore, the fact that the waiters wear matching uniforms and the tables have white cloths on them, is simply not convincing enough to make me enjoy paying nearly twice what I pay at other Indian food restaurants in the city.

We do have a paucity of good Indian restaurants in the city, and this one's not too bad.  But don't be fooled by the hype and the faux-fancy.  It's just not all that.
author: Ravena F.

description:
I'm coming up on 300 reviews and I've never written one for Indian Oven. This is about as close to a layup as there is. I was actually shocked to learn just now that I hadn't.

Anyway, the Oven is awesome, we all know that. I've berated Raja for feeding of their spillover business, but never properly expressed how good IO is. 

First of all, their lassis are legit and so is their naan. Two great places to start. Their appetizers (do they call those 'chaat'?) are so much superior to everyone else's in SF.

4 problems with Indian Oven: Location, Location, Location. And Parking.

I don't go there anymore, because who am I trying to impress? But, if a friend asked me for the best Indian in town, you know that's where I'm sending them.
author: Jason R.

description:
Has a meal ever moved you to tears? No, I'm not talking about JC and 12 of his closest friends at a certain supper, and sadly not about a spot at Thomas Keller's table (if he would EVER return my calls, typical guy). 

I'm talking about a tandoori oven whose aroma evoked tears to come gushing out of my eyes like Niagara Falls. For the love of Ganesh, Indian Oven, please ventilate! 

Still, some delicious chicken tikka masala, dal, and chicken biryani. It didn't have to make me cry though.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
I've been hearing about the wonders of Indian Oven for ages now, but it was actually the cooler than cool Joe C. who brought me to experience it earlier this week.  And it was AWESOME.  

Three words: Goat.  Cheese.  Naan.  Naan stuffed with herb goat cheese and topped with a little scoop of it, an interesting combo.  "Where does goat cheese come from?  Isn't it a European thing?", to which the wise Joe C. responded, "I think that it originally comes from goats actually".  Thanks, Joe C.

We also got rice, alu ghobi saag and fish masala.  The two dishes were more spicy and salty than I'm used to, but nonetheless delicious once I slathered it on rice and naan.  I haven't had fish this tender and flaky since I went pescatarian!  Mmmmm...

This restaurant is tiny, but they really maximize their space by putting in as many tables as possible.  Had it been a full house, I think I would've felt a bit claustrophobic!  But the rose stem and the candles on each table do add a nice touch :)
author: Debbie L.

description: Great food, fabulous service, fair price - we love this spot!
author: Lorie G.

description:
Why the great reviews? I have to go with Cheryl S. and agree that all I can  say about this place is "Meh." This place came highly recommended from my boss, and it's kind of like when your friend won't shut up about their new significant other and you get all excited about meeting  them and then you do and they're so lackluster it leaves you feeling empty, and then you feel guilty for not approving of them and then you wonder if there's something you're just not seeing or if your standards are really just that ridiculously high.

The service was "meh" as well. Our later server was attentive enough but our first server was kind enough to offer to take our chutney/dips to refill them and then never return.

My boyfriend and I shared Saag Paneer, Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Madras, Samosas, Jasmine Rice, plain Naan,  and a bottle of the Indian  Sula Sparkling Brut. It got a little pricey (over $60) and, honestly, the best part was the Brut! It was crisp and delicious and only $15 a bottle! 

The coconut sauce in the Chicken Madras was good, too, but, overall the meal was not worth the price.
author: Dee I.

description: I understand I missed my delivery but when I called you didnt have to be an ass and get all pissy over the phone. You had my money all I asked was if you could deliver it again. If you simply said no I can't or we have to charge you extra I would have understood. But instead you get all pissy and tell me Im such a horrible person gtfo.
author: Jose A.

description:
I had a solid four star dining experience here the other night, only to be knocked down to a four by the consistent and persistent slow door that allowed cold air to viciously attack our table every 5 minutes.  However, I blame this primarily on the mannerless customers of the establishment, and not the establishment itself. 

I think the indian here is awesome, and while I may not be a Connoisseur of Indian, and therefore unable to make authentic and practical debridements of the food, I thought it was pretty bomb ass!  We had a variety of treats, beginning with Veggie Pakoras and samosas.  Yummmy.  I had to put a muzzle on right there at the table to prevent myself from ruining the masala fantasy that was to follow. 

For entrees we had a little bit of everything cause, well, we were a big ass group so I was stoked to be munching on both chicken and prawn tandoori and some seriously yummy veggie curries.  All in all, a fantastic meal closely followed by some seriously couch surfing.  My favorite kind of night.  

Indian Oven's hooking it up in the Lower Haight.
author: Claire C.

description:
This is Indo-Pakistani food for Middle Americans. The food lacked any kind of spiciness or zip -- it was like they dumbed down the flavor and added more cream.

I'm not likely to go back here. Not terrible but really, where are plenty of better places in the city. Spend wisely.
author: Karsten P.

description:
Some of the worst Indian food I've had. Zagat is actually to blame this time for leading us astray. My friend and I ordered saag paneer and chicken tikka. Both were amazingly bland.

Service had us laughing it was so unpolished. The waiters all seemed very confused  - as if they had woken up just moments ago. At one point, one of the waiters was cleaning a table nearby and began to place items from THAT table onto OUR table, in order that he clean the other table. This, of course, seemed quite odd the first time he did it, but then later he did it again.

As the menu proudly proclaims, this restaurant has received many awards. I'm not sure how this happened. If these awards are legit, then something has gone terribly awry.
author: Denise N.

description:
I've been here 2 times...the second time under protest.  The food was respectable the first time but the second I was turned off by the amount of salt.  I will say the Naan is top notch. But let's face it-it's the curries that are important. 
First off, we live in WAY to diverse a city to pay this much for Indian food.  Go down the street-eat for 1/3 the price, enjoy the culture for what it is more like in India, not what the Brits made of it.  You can keep your white table cloths....I'm headed to Naan 'n Curry or Alhamra. word.
author: J P.

description: Well... It's food. That's about all. Very bland tasting with nothing special. If you are hungry, eating it will make you less so. If you want something tasty, skip on this one and go somewhere else.
author: Bishop J.

description:
UPDATE: The manager called me as soon as he saw my review, apologized and offered to send me dinner. I appreciate the attentiveness and quick response. Adding another star for customer service.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Disappointing chicken korma. Overpriced for the quality of food.

The wait for my take-out order was twice as long as they told me on the phone, but they didn't let me know once I was there. So I awkwardly hovered near the kitchen for 20 minutes. A word of apology or even just a heads up that they were running slow would have gone a long way towards a more positive experience.
author: MB T.

description:
Indian food is one of my comfort foods. When my friends suggested that we go to Indian Oven, a place that I'd never been, I was totally game. Was the food worth the hour long wait? 

The appetizer sampler came with a samosa, some vegetable pakoras, and papadum. The flavors were good and the vegetable pakoras were perfectly fried. Our entrees of Navratan Korma (vegetables in a cream sauce), Saag Paneer, and Jheenga Masala (prawns in tomato sauce) looked good, but lacked any memorable flavors. 

My recommendation for Indian in SF?  Rasoi in the Mission which has had consistently great flavors and no wait.
author: Joanna W.

description:
I went there with my friend, Linh N.  She had an orgasm in mid-sentence while eating.  Weirdest thing ever.

Yeah, I am never eating with her in public.  She'll probably give this place five stars.

The reviews for this place are really mixed.  As for me, I'll give it three stars.  The food was hit and/or miss.

Here is what I thought of some of my dishes:

-Goat cheese naan :: Eh.  Not for me.  And I love to eat cheese!  But it didn't do it for me, though.
-Chicken tikka masala :: My friend, Lisa T, heard this dish was good and ordered four plates.  Sorry Lisa, you ordered four plates too many b/c I wasn't feeling this either.  But I do like feeling on you.
-Butter Chicken :: Heck yes!  You should buy this.  It was delish.  And I never use the word "delish."
-Lamb plate :: I don't know what we got, but the lamb was freaking good too.

So, yeah, like i said, out of four dishes, I enjoyed 50%.  Hence, three stars.
author: Tony B.

description: Delicious, beautiful interior, and nice people.
author: Alex G.

description:
Why would anyone spend this kind of money for Indian food? It takes balls to charge $13.95 for Karahi Gosht in the lower Haight. They serve boring, dry naan, and dal that was runny and too salty.

But isn't the whole point of Indian cooking to get a lot of tasty dishes and then share them and eat them communally?  

Instead, here everyone's only able to afford one entree so there's not really enough to share -- which somehow turns it into a non-Indian meal!

My new mantra: "There's no place like Shalimar." 

Reason # 4,105 why I'm going to hell:  when confronted by an older homeless woman outside who asked for money saying, "I don't want to have to sell my body" the first thought that popped into my head was, "Wow, that's really still an option?!"
author: Adam Z.

description: We came reading the reviews, but were disappointed. The service was slow, the kitchen was noisy, the food was unseasoned, and the items over priced. Plus, hygiene for them didn't seem a priority. The silverware and plates were dusty and the hand wash in the bathroom wasn't replaced despite us mentioning it twice.
author: Suchitra C.

description: This review has nothing to do with the quality of food but only the horrible delivery service.  This place was recommended by a few people online so I thought I would give it a shot and have it delivered to a friend's place which I was visiting.  For delivery I was charged $4 which is pretty standard so no problems there.  The problem happened when the delivery was over a half hour late and the guy had the nerve to complain about the $3 tip that I gave on top of the $4 I originally paid.  My total was on $28 so I think a 25% tip for late food is more than enough.  San Francisco has plenty of places with much better food so if you want to avoid the chance of being insulted don't bother ordering from this place.
author: Shaun D.

description:
I had the worst Indian take-out in my life this past Friday evening.

I had a hankering for Indian food and, after a few fairly mediocre recent experiences with Indian take-out places, I surfed the web in search of some better options. I came across the Indian Oven website -- I had eaten at Indian Oven many times in the past (admittedly, not recently....), and I found the place to be fun & the food to be tasty & spicy. Take-out from Indian Oven seemed like a good bet -- and, they now had an online ordering system, so I didnt even need to go through the usual confusion of ordering my dishes. I keyed everything in, very smooth and easy -- a few minutes later, I got a call from the restaurant confirming my order. Everything seemed to be very well organized and efficient.

However, a LONG time went by - with no food. Then, I got a mysterious phone call from Igor (the Russian delivery guy, as it turned out.) They had managed to screw up my address - despite the fact that it was entered into the web order. He finally got to my house a little while later. But that was just the beginning my bad experience. I had ordered Chicken Vindaloo, and my friend got the Chicken Tikka Masala, along with rice and Samosas -- usually very reliable choices, and dishes I had had at the restaurant before. However, the Vindaloo was borderline inedible -- gray, disgusting, chewy chicken and hard potatoes in a heavily spiced thin soup. I came close to gagging, before I put it aside (and quickly, into the trash.) The Chicken Tikka Masala wasnt much better -- cold (a result of Igor's tour of the City, I suppose) and bland. The meat was slightly better than my dish, but overall, it was also very poor. Even the rice (described in the menu as "studded" with peas) contained almost no peas! Usually not a big deal - but here, it again pointed to the lack of interest Indian Oven had in serving good take-out food.

I went to bed hungry and disgusted, with a bad taste in my mouth (from the appalling food, among other things.)

The restaurant may still be acceptable. (I cannot say.) But, if you're thinking Indian take-out, go someplace else.
author: donal c.

description:
My favorite Indian restaurant!

I'm really not qualified to say anything specific about Indian food, all I know is that every time I visit my brother in San Francisco, I make a special request to eat here.  

Prices are reasonable, food is de-lish!
author: Kari L.

description:
I went here recently and was seriously not impressed. Actually, more like disappointed. My veggie dish was watery, flavorless and undercooked...for a whopping 9.75!!!!! I make better Indian food in my sleep. 

The naan was also highly disappointing, as I like it to be fluffy. Crispy on the outside and fluffy gooey on the inside. This was thin and crunchy.  It reminded me more of a Jewish Matzo cracker than a piece of delicious naan. 

The only thing this place has going for it is nice atmosphere and attentive service. But I'd rather serve myself for WAY less money and WAY better food at Tasty Curry or Naan and Curry... or just basically anywhere but here.
author: Maggie M.

description:
Ditto,

Great food Great Service.  Had teh Tikka Massala and teh Saag Paneer. Both great choices.  The Naan with Goat cheese was interesting but a little heavy. Don't think I'll be ordering it again.  I would definitely take a date here. The room gets a bit warm but all in all it's a great little indian restaurant.  The Tikka Massala is a lot better then Rotte's up the street.
author: Adam L.

description:
SO HOT.  OUCH.  Fire extinguisher needed.  No, two of them.

I like spicy food but by poor partner was begging for a cup of ice, which made the staff actually chuckle at us.  The samosas are little fire balls.  The curry is molten lava.

INTENSE flavors here.  Cute, tiny, little space.  I've been to most of the Indian joints in the area and this is the one worth returning to.  It's a little popular, so you may have to wait at peak times.
author: Aaron W.

description: We ordered take out from here last week. It was awful. I mean terrible! Very very greasy and the vegetables are not fresh and the food has no flavor. The worst part is that there were multiple bristle brush hairs mixed in with food. I will never eat here again.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great food!  If you can, just order in advance to-go because both times I've been there have been looonng waits.  We're talking 20-40 minutes.  However, if you're going for the food and don't mind the service, then go for it.  For the best of both worlds, go to Indian Clay Oven in the outer richmond!!
author: THUY N.

description:
Bland Indian food for bland, boring people.  If you think authentic Indian has too much flavor, you should try Indian Oven.  You'll love it.  If you like Eliza's for Chinese, you'll probably like Indian Oven for Indian.

On a sidenote, if you ever need to entertain some corporate lawyers/schmoes-- take them to Indian Oven.  They'll love it AND rave to their friends about it.
author: Poker B.

description:
If you are a Brit, this place is shite.


It only gets a star so I can warn you. 

The naan was more like a roti, and my jalfrezi had a sauce like friggin' gravy.  My fellow  diners where shocked that I could be such a curry snob.
I felt guilty for my American colleague who, to date, has been spot on when selecting where we should eat.  OK, I admit I said to him "another great choice here", but I value his friendship.
author: Berty B.

description:
All I can really say about this place is ..."Meh..."

I went fairly early on a weekday evening, and it was surprisingly packed. I was seated next to a portable dishwasher? The decor is boring and trying to be upscale, yet the kitchen seems to be directly in the dining room. 

This is also the only Indian restaurant I've been to that doesn't offer those thin crackers and chutney when you sit down. The naan was fairly bland, and the portions were small. My palak paneer had a nice medley of spices, and was very flavorful, although it didn't pack as much heat as I like. 

Overall, my experience wasn't bad, but I don't think there is any reason for me to go back a second time.
author: Cheryl J.

description:
Went back to the Indian Oven last night with the bf to check it out again, just in case & yet again was disappointed. The service wasn't rushed this time, but the food still sucks arse. My chicken tikka masala didn't seem to have seen the inside of a tandoor, so it was more like chicken masala...and a really bland, watery masala at that. The naan breads are tiny, especially for the price...they're a bit more like chapati than naan...naan should be fatter & fluffier. The BF's lamb dish was equally as bland & the veggie samosas aren't any better than at 'naan n chutney'. If you want watered down, americanised indian, then maybe the Oven is the place for you. We'll stick with Pakwan in the mission - cheaper and way, way better. 

Original review:

I grew up eating Indian food, having lived in the UK for most of my life, so I like to think I know good Indian food. Indian Oven isn't it...definitely the worst I've ever had. Considering the hype, awards and lines outside, I had high hopes...I've been looking for a restaurant that does Indian food the way they do back home and figured maybe this will finally be the end of my hunt. Alas, I'm still hunting.

The service was probably the worst part of the meal...my friend and I were so rushed, I felt like as though we were in a race with everyone else in the restaurant to see who could eat the fastest...our main course was brought out before we'd finished the appetizer and we were offered coffee and brought the bill whilst we were still munching on the entree. Not wanting indigestion, and being a cantankerous so-and-so, I made sure to eat as slow as I could.

As for the food...bland and watery. I had the chicken tikka...well, that's what they claimed it was. I think maybe they wafted the chicken above the marinade for a minute, rather than immersing it and letting it infuse. Result - chunks of tasteless chicken breast. I also had a vegetable curry as a side dish, which was an absolute joke...I think I counted three pieces of vegetable in there. It was more like a vegetable soup than a curry.

So, as you may have guessed, I will never again fork over my hard earned dosh for such crummy fare. If there's any justice in this world, people will see the light of day and this place will go out of business real soon. My advise, therefore, is to avoid it like the plague and head to Raja on the corner of Haight & Fillmore - there's no wait and the food is yummy...so much so, that I eat there at least twice a week. 

Oven Schmoven.
author: Dan L.

description:
"Time/Date: Tuesday 7:40 pm

Type/Quality: Indian Food for xenophobic Americans. If you have never had indian food and would rather be eating your usual diet of tatter tots and bread this is the right place. I can't belive this place is zaggat rated...

Price/Quanity: Around  $40 dollars, about 25 bucks too much, feeds 2 people really well. So does hometown Buffet. Don't get me wrong the food isn't bad; the favors are  basic but good but the meat is dry and was probably frozen. I think they tried to compensate by marinating the meat to replace the lost tenderness.

Service/Accesibility: The wait was actually quick for us but I think we were lucky. The food also came out quickily. The staff is friendly but they aren't attentive. Luckily the place is small so getting water quickily, I'm a camel, is easy.

Structure/Ambience: So this is why its zaggat. You walk in and the place is arranged perfectly. The atmosphere is great, and while its a small venue you feel like you have alot of space. If the food was good it would be a great date spot.
author: Justin L.

description:
wow.. amazing.  I was skeptical, when i went to this fine establishment.  IO thought, how good can Indian get?  The quality is impeccable,,  the food melted in my mouth.  I'm used to  eating at the cheaper Indian establishments.. which are delicious, but a bitt heavy..  Indian oven was light and ddelicious.. and my tummy didnt feel the food , like i usually do with Indian..

Highly Recommended
author: Georgio S.

description:
This is the whitest Indian food I have ever eaten.  

The aloo mattar was bland, the potatoes were under cooked, the sauce... oh my god the sauce.  If I were to eat real Indian food, have a night full of excessive drinking, and vomit into the sink the next morning while attempting to brush my teeth, I'm positive that the contents of my sink would be infinitely more delectable than whatever recipes Indian Oven is currently using.  Look around, is there a single Indian person eating in this establishment?  No, no there is not.  Thanks but no thanks.
author: steve m.

description:
A bit on the pricey side but they are the only Indian restaurant I have found in the city that isn't greasy or scuzzy. Their smoky fish curry is quite excellent. 

Word on the street is that they closed due to a fire in mid May but will be reopening on June 16.
author: matt m.

description:
My girlfriend & I love this place for it's delicious food steaming hot, and cute waiters. We like the attention, but we just wish we didn't smell like the food when we walked out.  It's like a steam curry room in there.
worth a visit... if you don't mind the inconvenient clothes smell !
author: Tarabud J.

description:
As I write this, my friend and I are lying on the floor holding our stomachs. Well, I am typing, she is holding her stomach. The point being we are literally experiencing some gastro-pain from our recent outing to Indian Oven. 
The meal itself was OK. We got the Dal Soup, which was decent. A little thin but very spicy.
For the main course, we ordered some standard dishes, Mataar Paneer and Aloo Ghobi. Both were ok, not particualary well seasoned. The Aloo Ghobi was a bit different than any other I had ever had with large amounts of diced tomatoes and onions. 
We ordered an onion kulcha (onion naan). It lacked the doughy goodness one would expect. 
The rice was standard.
The real highlight of the meal was the wine, which was reasonably priced and flavorful.

Overall the meal was fine, but within minutes of leaving the restaurant we both noticed acute pain in our upper stomachs. Half an hour later we are still experiencing the repercussions.  Did we just order poorly?
I plan on never going back to the Indian Oven.
author: Ben H.

description:
Tried Indian Oven on the recommendation of many in the neighborhood, and wasn't terribly impressed.  The service was attentive, the atmosphere nice, and the naan was quite good.  

However, I remember little else about the food - perhaps that says all that needs to be said....unremarkable and pricey.  There are two other Indian restaurants in the Lower Haight, Raja and Naan n' Chutney, that are cheaper and better.
author: Alison L.

description:
The prices for lunch were way too high-everything a la carte
just the entree was eleven dollars and it was horrible
The room itself is nice but it seems the staff/owners have no business sense
as the rest of the street was buzzing and the restaurant was empty
No luncheon special
We sat at the table a long time with no staff
Went there many years ago and it was great but now
it has fallen
author: enythe g.

description:
Table-clothed Indian/Pakistani food, kinda oxymoron. Pretty good food, a hideaway upstairs that is much more quiet and relaxed than seeing the servers rushing around.

I still prefer hole-in-the-wall in the Tenderloin...
author: T L.

description:
My gold standard for Indian food is the India Chaat House (see my Portland restaurant reviews), and this place just doesn't measure up, plus it costs way more. Pretty good food, though, in fact I would give them 3.5 stars if possible. The decor and atmosphere is nice, especially compared to a truck in a parking lot (yeah, pretty tough to beat).  I was surprised how small it looked from the front, until I saw the SECRET back room. Okay, so it's not a secret, but my dinner companions, who had been there several times before, didn't know about it, so it was at least hidden. 
Would I go back? I wouldn't suggest it, but I wouldn't too strongly protest it.
author: Rachel J.

description:
I am so torn, because I hate the wait and felt the service was spotty, but that damn butter chicken is so tasty!
We went here again last night and waited at least 45 minutes to be seated.  I know that's par for the course, but when I'm hungry, I also get grumpy.  So, it's not fun for anyone when I wait around and watch other people eat.  
When we finally got seated, we had to flag someone down to take our order after waiting and waiting to be noticed.  But, once the food came, my irritation was assuaged by the deliciousness in my mouth.  I am perpetually on the search for excellent butter chicken and was quite pleased.  On the flipside, we got a lamb dish, too, with potatoes and peas, and it was just ok.  The lamb was almost minced, and I was craving big, tasty chunks.
I think from now on I'll do take-out.  Less grumpiness all around
author: Jessica L.

description:
Okay, so I come from a country that colonized India (I'm not proud of it) so am used to that particular version of Indian food, i.e. stick a tine of your fork in the vindaloo and it burns your whole face off. So, my experience is "I've had 18 pints of beer and need a curry at 11 PM" with a bit of ring-burn on the side the next AM and was fully expecting to be disappointed with the bland s*** that the "other side of the pond" crowd seem to like (who heard of Indian freakin' salad, FFS (for f***'s sake?). 

Anyhoozer, not to cheesy at all, quite frankly. Not squalid enough for yer local post-closing-time (the pubs, that is) curry house, but the food is flavorful and the service decent - er...like a Real Restaurant or something. 

The usual litmus test of chicken tikka masala, sag aloo, pilau and naan passed the test with flying colors. Poppadoms and fixin's too. And beer (always beer). As they say in Old Blighty, "this one's a bit of all right!"
author: Mi M.

description:
One of my favorite places in SF. I used to live in London, so I know from Indian food, and this place is fantastic.

However, here's my beef with this place: they charge for rice. I mean, come on! WTF? I've eaten Indian food all over the country and, as said, in London and I've NEVER been asked to pay for rice! What would you have me do, Indian Oven, eat my tikka masala like soup?!

But at the end of the day, it's an extra $3. A small price to pay for what I'm told--and heartily believe--is the best Indian food in SF.
author: John S.

description:
We had a great dinner here.  I can't add much beyond what others have said, so I'm keepin it short.  My favorite part was the interior, it was like having dinner over at your friend's house...Ya know that  friend who just got their kitchen remodeled: Granite counter tops, cherry stained cabinets and stainless steel appliances.  haha!  The kitchen is open to the dining room which I'm always a fan of.

The food was really good and the service was prompt.  We started with calamari (dipped in chickpea batter) which I'd highly recommend.  For the entrees we had Chicken Saagwala (the chicken was SO tender) and Chicken Vindaloo (oh yum - those potatoes)... both great choices.  We'll definitely go back!

Because the kitchen is open to the dining room (and its kinda small) it does get warm in there.  Like I should have worn a tank top warm.
author: Tracey E.

description:
One afternoon I was returning from work and saw a mess of fire trucks congregating around the corner of Haight and Fillmore.  My first thought: "Sh**, my house is on fire.  Great."  My second thought: "Damn, Indian Oven better not be on fire.."

My house wasn't on fire.  Indian oven was.  I wept a little.

The fire was put out and about a month later, the restaurant reopened.  I beamed, and that night my girl and I ate very well. 

The food here, on a good day, is truly transcendantal.  Not everything is perfect but the dishes IO nails, they really nail.  Spices in perfect proportions, wonderful textures, the best chutney tray in SF, good (if pricey) wine selection, excellent papadums (though I wish they were complimentary- they're addictive), samosas to die for, dal to soothe the savage bea(n)st, wonderful saag everything, and chana masala that makes me say, "Hmmmm.."

They've got it all.

Why four stars then?  Well, I'm an inveterate cheapskate and a hoity-toity cook/foodie- a bad combo for eating out.  It's hard for me to get through a classy dinner without thinking, "Aww, man, I coulda made some bitchin' goong prik king and tom yum for like $2..." 

This place costs some money.  I can only go when I'm feeling a little flush.  I mean, $40 for dinner for two + beer isn't going to rend my wallet in twain but it kicks my snobbery into high gear in the way that a $4 sausage from Rosamunde's doesn't.  Flaws seem amplified when you're paying mid-level ducats for them.

To sum up, Indian Oven reeks class and sophistication in flavor, good service, a nice but not stuffy vibe, and...  It's around the corner from my house.  When I stay away too long I get an ache for it, if that helps any.
author: George C.

description:
Yum, I ate here last night and found this place serves a great, fast Indian meal.

My gf dropped my broken-legged arse off in front of the restaurant then went off to find parking. When I walked in, I found the entrance to be a little claustrophobic especially with crutches in-tow. After entering, I was quickly directed to the upstairs seating by the staff
BTW 
it's really fun to traverse stairs with crutches but in this city its kind of hard to do anything w/o encountering them. 

After my stair-adventure I was seated at my table that happened to be right next to the wait-staff station and silverware cabinet. I almost jumped outta my chair when one of the staff dumped a bunch of silverware into the cabinet with a crash that was far louder than you might expect (think of someone nailing a crash cymbal right next to your ear). 

Indian Oven people - Maybe you could make more of an effort to limit the silverware noise pollution at the table right next to your upstairs wait station? Or maybe its a fun diversion for your wait staff to get people a jumpin' and a bumpin' around??

I got a menu quickly and ordered a Taj Mahal beer and samosas before gf arrived. It took about 5 minutes for the samosas to come and they did so before said gf who arrived looking more than a little pissy telling me about the parking nightmare she endured to find a spot after dropping my gimpy ass off... sometimes this handicap does have its advantages. I calmed her down by letting her know that food and beer were to be had in very short order, that seemed to sorta work, I turned that frown upside down.

We ordered garlic naan, some nice rice, chicken tikka and aloo gobhi.  We both found the food to be fresh and very flavorful. The chutney was good and the yogurt a standout.  I did ask for extra spicy and wasn't very impressed by what they think "extra spicy" means. I got the caucasian version of extra spicy. C'mon people, when I ask for extra spicy, I want to FEEL my food. Also, while the garlic naan was good there wasn't much of it.  Anyhoo other than those very minor quibbles, everything was excellent.
author: Sam T.

description:
The remodel is nice but the service needs refreshment.
 Our salad dressing was served in a 'to go' plastic container,  there was a dead cockroach in the bathroom, we had to stack and bus our own table to make room for our entree.  They just didn't seem into it, obviously. The food was ok not fabulous- it used to be.
The man answering the phones and taking delivery orders was  pleasant but on a Friday eve,on date night, the whole experiance was sadly lack luster.
author: Lola P.

description:
It amazes me when people line up outside this restaurant for a table.

Except for the samosas, nothing was really good. The baingan barta was the least horrible of what we had. The chickpea curry was watery. The tea was horrible, per my friend. And the gulab jamuns we had as dessert was cold. Service was kinda crap too.

Makes me wonder why people go here. Only Indian restaurant in Lower Haight?
author: Premshree P.

description:
3.5 stars.  

came here on Saturday for a friend's bday party. it really is a lovely space.  Also, the service was great, and I found the food to be quite good.  I would have given it four stars if there had been more consistency in the dishes.  With such a large party, we ended up getting a ton of stuff; like 6 or 7 main dishes and some breads and appetizers.  I thought the samosas were really good, but their naan had a gummy consistency to it, and the goat cheese naan just didnt' taste good.  I believe we also got lentil wafers, which were delicious.  Among the main dishes, I really liked about half of them.  I don't necessarily know that the others were bad, so much as not really in line with my taste.  One thing I didn't appreciate, however, was the uncleanliness of their glasses.  The drinks all had a smell to them, and there were still stains encrusted on the rims of the glasses.  All in all, however, I'd come back here.  It was, in my opinion, a very reasonably priced place for the quality of food and environment.
author: Ash T.

description: I came here with friends and we ordered a bunch of different things. The flavors were decent but not mind blowing like other restaurants I've been to. The shrimp with almonds in red curry is #1. #2 would be the Samosas and Naan. My Chicken Tikka Masala was good but for some reason reminded me too much of tomato bisque rather than curry/masala. The atmosphere is really cute and the service is good. I'm still looking for that ONE excellent mind blowing Indian experience in SFO though.
author: Lily M.

description:
One of the best Indian food places in the City!

My absolute favorite place for Fish Tandoori - it's like pure ecstasy, melt-in-your-mouth-make-your-toes-curl-and-wish-you-could-have-a-cigarette-after kinda dish.  

The Chicken Tikka Masala is amazing too - you'll thank yourself for utilizing all remaining naan bread to soak up every last drop of the most delectable sauce!

I can't say that I've had anything bad here - everything is made with the freshest ingredients and beautifully prepared.  Service is impeccable and the ambiance very nice.  Makes for a nice romantic meal, except it can get quite loud in here.

The restaurant is very small and parking is horrid.  There's usually a wait, but it's so worth it.  Prices are not for the budget minded, but well worth the caliber of food and service you receive here.
author: Christy L.

description:
I have been a lot to this restaurant and used to like it a lot.
Until about 2 weeks ago when the service went terribly wrong.
It was on a Sunday night, on a very busy day in SF (Castro fair, bluegrass festival among other events) and the restaurant was much more crowded than usual (the back room was full).
The service took forever and was erratic: we never got the appetizer we ordered, got only 3 of the 4 main courses we ordered, after well over 1h of wait, and they arrived somewhere between warmish and cold.
Then when we wanted to pay we had to hail the servers at least half a dozen time to finally get our bill, which evidently hadn't been corrected for the items not served.
Relatively speaking we were lucky: most of the tables around us, that arrived 5-10 min after us, still didn't have their food when we left. Those people had been there for a good 2h!!
author: Jean T.

description:
It was unfortunate that hubby got food poisoning after we dined at this restaurant. I, along with our friend Gerri who was looking forward to revisiting this restaurant and raved about this place so many times, were absolutely fine. 

We all had the Chilean seabass sizzling with lemon and potatoes, chicken tikka masala and tandori chicken. They also serve complimentary mango chutney with your dishes.  Yum!
author: Miles G.

description:
I judge an Indian Restaurant by it's Naan.  Unfortunately, the Naan at this location was sparse and flat.  Good Naan is supposed to be substantial, fluffy, floury and a bit doughy (in my opinion).

The dishes were average except the Saag Paneer which was delicious and a bit spicy.  The rice was also delicious with little appearances  of pees.

The location was small and intimate, but the open kitchen layout made it very noisy and drafty.
