The price was right and the service was good.

VEggie Friendly: Yes, lots of veggie options
author: ashley l.

description:
I really like Indian Oven. It's the kind of place to go for a step up* (both in food and ambiance) on Naan & Curry and Pakwan. My buddy saw the white tablecloths and started blabbin' bourgeois this and bourgeois that but he was quickly silenced by the delicious food.

*I must admit that the Naan bread is weak here compared to Nann & Curry.
author: Brian W.

description:
Definitely one of the better Indian places in the City. Their chicken tikka masala is my favorite...I could eat that with naan all day long. I like how it is a little more high class (think cloth napkins) than most Indian places, but you can still eat there wearing a t-shirt. 

I'm knocking one star off because we felt rushed. There was plenty of open tables, and no one was walking in the door, so there wasn't a need to turn the table over...and we didn't want to leave yet as it was still raining.
author: Grant F.

description:
I guess this is kind of like "moderate upscale" Indian cuisine.  The ambiance is all table cloths and candles, but the food is kind of "generic-we-forgot-the-spices" Indian.  The samosas are quite good, but the chicken tikka masala was lacking. Naan 'n Curry's was better to be honest, and half the price. 

Yes, there is a wait, and yes it's all white people.  I never once saw any Indian people there, and there's probably a good reason for that.
author: MrsKimch I.

description:
I thought this place had very yummy, classy Indian food.  The interior is a little boring - it's trying to look upscale but doesn't have anything "Indian" or even colorful to liven the place up.  If you're seated upstairs, you feel a little cut off from the rest of the restaurant... when I went anyway, it was pretty quiet and odd.  It would feel cozier if the tables and chairs weren't so big.

The food doesn't taste very authentic to me, but it was still delicious!!  I heart Naan.. and having the choice of 10 different kinds of Naan including garlic and goat cheese??  That was awesome... I would definitely go here again, but I'm going to try some other Indian places around the city first.
author: Laura W.

description:
so good!! 
best chicken tikka masala i've ever had. 
goat cheese naan will blow you away. it could use a little butter though (can't everything?) 
saag mushroom (spinach./mushroom) was light and perfectly cooked.
wine was fantastic, after we let it air a bit. 
cherry on top was our waiters hair. loved it.

and bill comes with a yummy little  rice pudding, on the house!
author: Nikki H.

description:
The three stars are almost entirely for the sauces.  These people really should start a new restaurant and call it "Salsa Bombay".  If you want to confuse your friends, tell them they can eat the whole dish, but hoard the naan and go mad cow on the leftover juiciness.  Don't stress the curry smell on your fingers; they give you a moist towelette at the end.

Happy dipping.
author: Daniel D.

description:
The food here is really good!  Slightly overpriced (like everything in SF)...
But the quality of the chicken is better than most, and the Nhavratan Korma (if you're a vegetarian) is delicious!

Tonight I had the samosas as starters and they were sooo spicy and delicious.  I'm a fan of spice and this got my nose running.  I'm always pleasantly surprised when they don't make it mild just to accomodate the pansy palates.  :P 

The service was really decent and the upstairs seating feels a little more romantic than the lower level.  

Go here over the Naan N' Curry around the corner.  It's better here.
author: Kirsten B.

description:
For my very first yelp review, I thought I should focus on one of my favorite restaurants in the city. When I moved to SF a year ago, I immediately set out on a quest to find the best Indian food in the city. I was wholly unimpressed, until a friend found Indian Oven in an ad in some free paper. Desperate, I tried it. 

It was amazing, and it keeps me going back for more! The Chicken Korma is unlike anything I've had at another Indian restaurant... it is to die for! Everything I have tried here, I've loved... the Korma, Chicken Tikka Masala, Chicken Tandoori, and Chicken Saag, to name a few. 

The only unfortunate part is the cost, so I knocked off one star for that. This restaurant costs more than any other Indian food place I've been. Although the food is great, the cost keeps me from frequenting as much as I otherwise would. I am a grad student, after all! But the moral of the story is TRY IT. You won't be disappointed!
author: Bridgette A.

description:
My favorite Indian restaurant in the city. I highly recommend the chicken korma and garlic naan. You can either eat there in the restaurant (parking is a bitch) or get it to-go. Either way, the service is always pleasant and efficient. The food is delicious. It's no wonder why they are always busy. Get there early for dinner.

Not open for lunch.  :(
author: Kathleen N.

description:
My good pal Rusty O. laid this down as one of the better Indian places in the Lower Haight, but I gotta say I think it's just "ok".

This place get big points for being really nice inside; table cloths, cloth napkins and candle light.  Good for taking out that old friend or family visitor who thinks you've hit the big time just because you live in SF (though in reality you eat at Love N' Haight 4 times a week).

The food was good.  The one stand out was the Chicken Sagawala which I was impressed with given that the spinach flavor was very fresh.  I feel that the spinach flavor of saag dishes tends to get lost or be weak at a lot of other places.  This place also serves Taj Mahal beer and while not being a terribly great beer, it is refreshing and does go well with the spicier foods.  Additionally, this place is usually open until 11pm on most nights.

The big hit comes in that three dishes, an order of naan, a plate of rice, two drinks and $65 (w/ tip) later, I feel I could have had an equal experience and been just as satisfied at Naan 'N Chutney for at least $15 cheaper.  Pricey doesn't bother me except when it tastes like something less pricey (and easily attainable).  The naan was small and nothing special.

Sorry Rusty O., I gotta roll with N 'n C for the time being....
author: Steven R.

description:
Some of the BEST Indian food in the states. Even my friends from the UK (where Indian food is VERY good) commented that this was not only the best Indian food they had in the states but possibly better than all the UK places! 
 

You will not be disappointed!

-Robb
http://twitter.com/robblewis
author: Robb L.

description: My husband and I wandered in on a rainy day hoping for some great food. The samosas were by far the worst that either of us had ever eaten, yet they were the most edible thing that we ordered. In addition to the food quality, the restaurant was empty and the service was still horrible.
author: Jamie Lee R.

description:
The food was really good!!  I enjoyed it.  The portions were just right.

We started off with the Samosas were yummy!!!  Just the right amount of spice.  And, the Bombay Pakora was tastey.

I had the Chicken Tikka Masala - which was scrumptious!!  My date has the Chicken Korma, as he prefers more of a mild flavor.

The lemonade and the iced tea were both bland and unmemorable.  The service was good at first, as they were too busy; but seemed to get lax as the place filled up.  Parking of course is an issue in that neighborhood.

I would highly recommend the restaurant.  Thanks!!
author: Charles L.

description:
As usual, the Yelpers have it right with the three-and-a-half star average.

Nothing too exciting here, just decent Indian food.  I had the Baingan Bartha and my friend had Saag Paneer.  An appetizer of Samosas that were REALLY tough to break into but filled with standard samosa stuff (their chutney was more like a jelly but really good still), and order of garlic naan and some tasty rice rounded out the meal.

I agree you can get the same meal for cheaper at Pakwan or some other cafe-style Indian restaurant.  But if you're in a white table-cloth kinda mood, it's a fair cop.

Bah, this review is way less spicy than the Baingan Bartha, which was not that spicy at all...
author: Kevin H.

description:
The food here is delicious, and not of the greasy reputation that is often associated with Indian food. The lamb dish we had (Lamb Korma) came in a delicious yogurt sauce, very tender and a perfect foil to the flavorful, brightly colored chicken tikka masala which was subtly spicy, very tomatoey, and overall perfect for a chilly winter night. 

The jasmine rice had a delicate aroma and color,  and a mild taste which made it more interesting than your average white rice. And the dessert selection, while smaller than other Indian restaurants I've been to, stocked the classics and prepared them well. Indian rice pudding (Kheer) was subtle and a real treat, with a slight herbal flavor offsetting the buttery sweet taste of the rice. A single portion was perfect for two.
author: Roman R.

description: The food is some of the best Indian that I've had in SF, but the service leaves something to be desired...  Also, it's pretty pricey compared to the other Indian Food in the neighborhood.
author: Casey C.

description:
Worst Indian food EVER, and I like and eat a lot of Indian.  Busy and expensive and just straight up BAD food.  Shocked by the number of good reviews.  It's just bad!

Ordered 3 main dishes and samosas.  Samosas were good, everything else was terrible.

Bland, very runny liquidy sauces for all 3 dishes.

Tikka Masala horrible - smokey flavor.  maybe their spices are limited to Liquid Smoke.  In any case, really gross

Lamb Vindaloo - ordered spicy, came mild, same liquidy sauce issue

Chana Masala - best of the three, still pretty crappy, same liquidy sauce issue

Naan - could've been better, could've been worse

Garlic Naan - same deal, could've been better, could've been worse

Rice - Standard

Raita - Standard
author: David G.

description:
I like Indian oven a lot.
Admittedly it has its flaws, but really i enjoy it. 

The prawn vindaloo? Delicious! 

I like my food spicy so it fits my taste buds accordingly. 
Though the curries are really watery as opposed to thick... ive discovered that the next day i can cut my curry contents and eat it as soup. Curry soup?! Strange as it may sound, i really enjoyed it. Though i am a curry addict. 

The naan tastes really fresh to me and the calamari appetizer is so good! 

Give it a try, i think you'll find you'll like it.
author: Amy M.

description: We ordered Chicken Tikka Masala and Mushroom Masala (and naan). We were really disappointed. It was very watery, tasteless, and gave us food poisoning. We love keeping leftovers to eat the next day but these leftovers went straight in the trash. To top it off, these dishes cost WAY MORE than most indian restaurants that we order from.  DISAPPOINTING.
author: alex g.

description:
Good, but not great Indian food that is slightly over priced. Try out the 'loin for some cheaper, spicier, and more interesting places, or just wander around lower haight where you'll run into a good, cheaper indian place. 
If you do go - get there early, and try the eggplant.
author: Anika K.

description:
Hadn't had Indian Oven in a while.  I'm lazy and I usually order delivery from Rotee.  My memory told me that Indian Oven was better.  So I went to the lower Haight and picked up some food.  My memory was wrong.  
It was still fine.  But it wasn't what I remembered.  The naan was so-so, the Chana Masala was just not that tasty, and the sauce was WAY too watery.  Plus, it was expensive...The one highlight were the samosas--now those were great.  
Don't get me wrong.  I enjoyed my meal.  I just wished I had stayed at home in the Upper Haight and had Rotee come to me.
author: Blake W.

description:
Dude, talk about overrated. Like others have said, I've always seen people waiting outside, but now I'm all "Please, just go to Naan N Chutney. It's better and cheaper."

The food isn't horrible, by any means. Just not worth the hike in price.
author: Veronica B.

description: went for lunch and was great. I do not eat Indian very often but would go here over Dosa.
author: Bryan M.

description:
Okay, so being Indian doesn't give you an edge guys.  It just gives you a browner tongue to taste things with.  I'm Italian and I'm pretty sure that mozzarella and basil taste the same to you as they do to me.  So enough already with your crazy-ass magical ethnic appeals to authority. 

This place is the shit for the same reasons that some people have attacked it: they let the flavor of the ingredients co-exist with the spices, cream and ghee.  Now, I love Indian food, lets make that clear right now, but you gotta admit that sometimes its like getting punched in the face with spice and kicked in the gut with fat.  Not so much at this place.  I mean, you order saag paneer, it tastes like spinach, which doesn't really happen most everywhere else.  And its a good thing.

Their food isn't watery, its just not entirely based on heavy cream.  I mean you can even order Chicken Tikka Masala and not feel like throwing up afterward.  

I really love this place, and if you're not looking to mop up a hangover or just self-destruct on rich food, you're gonna love it too.  The wine is super cheap, the staff is super courteous, the place is super clean.  The food is actually treated with delicacy.  The ingredients, including the meats, are of high quality and the general ambiance is light years from your typical frescos of women in sarongs and bad lighting.

Oh, do yourself a favor and order the Saag Paneer.

One more thing, this is not a scary neighborhood to whoever said that.
author: Bill P.

description:
I've had mixed experiences here, on all fronts. The first time I went the food was amazing and the service was great. Fast-forward to three months later and this time all our chicken dishes (makani and tikka masala) had overcooked meat that kind of killed the deliciousness of the sauce. Also the waiters were a little sloppy and when we asked for more rice it took them 20 minutes to get it to us, WTF. 

We ended up paying 80.00 for 3 main dishes, rice, appetizer, a bowl of soup and mango lassi. Personally I thought that was steep when you consider that Naan & Chutney and Roti are all 1 block away and much cheaper.
author: Venatius P.

description:
Had some excellent, delicious, spicy lamb. Mmmmm

The naan was quite burnt though, and the prices were a bit on the expensive side. Also, complementary plain naan and rice would have been nice. Major props for having two floors though, you don't see that very often in the Lower Haight.
author: Mark A.

description: Excellent service and good food. Had the chicken korma and tandoori chicken, which is served sizzling on the plate.
author: K Z.

description:
Let it be known! I witnessed (while I was dining) Internet darling Leah Culver enter Indian Oven, use the facilities, then leave. All on a Saturday night.

Busted!

That aside, Indian Oven has good food, quick and very friendly service, and decent prices. The ambiance inside is a little... drab. Usually I like my Indian restaurants a little noisy and more colorful.
author: Trey F.

description:
I've"ve been coming here for years.  
The last time I went there was about 2 months ago.  The place was empty.  This was my favorite but it has gotten worse after their change of ownership (or something).  I remember, we used to have to wait for hour if I just stopped by.  Not any more.

I like vegetarian stuff at Indian restaurant and their curries were spectacular - now just OK.  Their Bengan Bartha was my favorite and unfortunately it tastes different now.  I still like their Chicken Saagwala.
author: Yuko K.

description:
I do not have a distinguished Indian food palate but I think IO tastes pretty darn good,  though I do think it's strange that the times I have been there, not one single Indian person is there....I suppose that speaks volumes I think Steve M. is on to something.  I enjoy the Benghan Bharta with some Naan, though it is a little spicy and might make one's nose run...

WARNING: It's a small joint with an open kitchen so be prepared to smell like everyone's meal when you leave.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Be prepared to feel a bit awkward when dining at Indian Oven. The experience is rather haphazard, beginning with the seating. We were routed to a table that got blasted with cold air everytime someone opened the front doors. I beyotched, they redeployed the waitstaff, and they reseated us next to the warm kitchen. Here, the generous menu calmed us down. 

* Calamari salad was one notch above average, but...
* The onion kulcha was unimpressive. 
* The tandoori chicken, perhaps their specialty, was not fully cooked! I could hardly believe this, but the staff gladly corrected it promptly, and it was very tasty the second time around.  
* The lamb jalfrezi, although healthy, had a sauce that leaned toward gritty and bulbuous, and we might have done a little better with the vindaloo.
* The rice pudding smoothly topped off these hits and misses, and by that time I was over the general awkwardness. 

Despite the detractors from this first visit of ours, the food and the impressive service were good enough to demand a few more visits. Maybe if they pull everything together, they just might squeeze out an extra star!
author: Daniel C.

description:
Wow, it's amazing how useful Yelp can be, even though I admit I feel like it's "jumped the shark" more often than not. I went to the Oven tonight though without checking Yelp, and the wife and I were really surprised by a couple of things.
1. The lack of a crowd and waiting list to get in. We've been about 5 - 10 times in the past 5 years or so and this is the first time we have been, on a Friday night nonetheless where there wasn't a wait. There were in fact several empty tables. We were pretty shocked. It did fill up by the time we left but there was still no wait. Strange.
2. The food was not as good as we remembered it. Not knowing that the ownership has changed, I was a little confused by this. The samosas were very tasty, but everything else was mediocre. The Daal soup was bland, watery and tasteless. Campbell's soup tastes better. I had the fish masala, which is Chilean Sea Bass (I know, they shouldn't be serving this, I thought it was outlawed) in masala sauce with Daal and garlic naan. The fish masala was ok, but it was not as good as I remembered it from before. The naan was a bit chewy but satisfactory. The Daal was not bad, but not great. The wife ordered the mushroom and pea dish not spicy and it came out extremely spicy, almost to the point of not being able to eat it. 
It's strange how you can sometimes sense things like a management or ownership change in a place you loved without knowing it beforehand. I definitely noticed a downgrade in quality, I just wasn't sure if my palate had been upgraded over time or what (I am in love with Amber India). I don't hate Indian Oven now, the dishes are fine, but they are not the same, sadly. They are watered down, too runny (the curries), and just not as good as they were. 
Sorry to the staff and owners to criticize. I have a policy to almost always only write a Yelp review unless I can rave and pump up my experience at a place, but sometimes something needs to be said if it's a big disappointment. Our waiter was a perfect gentleman and nice, even though the service wasn't great. 
In summary this is decent Indian food if you're in the hood but no longer worthy of going out of your way for. Too much competition for stellar Indian in the City now I guess (Dosa, Shalimar, Amber and that one in the Mission that people are raving about).
author: Matt H.

description: Extremely overpriced for ok food. The decor is nicer than most indian restaurants, but if you're only interested in the quality of food and service, stay away, go to Naan n' Curry around the corner or Tikka Masala... same food for half the price.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
If my first Indian food experience had been like it was last night, I wouldn't have avoided and hated it all these years.

We went with my BF, his best friend, the best friend's parents and the best friend's GF (who is also someone I work with) so the tally went like this: 4 die-hard indian food loving Brits, 1 midwestern girl and me, a little Asian girl.  There really was no question where we'd go to dinner. 

The ambiance was lovely, white table cloths, waiters with sparkly silver trimmed vests, little vases of flowers on the table.  They have a real tandori oven to make the naan, the kitchen is open and bustling, the service is friendly and not too slow.

We ordered a lot of food.  The standouts were the Samosas (fried bits of heaven, not to be eaten everyday), Tandori Assorted (salad with different meats from the oven like lamb, chicken and kebab, to be eaten everyday), Lamb Jalfrezi (heart healthy with bell peppers and not too creamy sauce), Dal Saag (lentil and spinach, SO DELICIOUS!!!).  We ate and ate and ate.

The back half of the room was filled with a bunch of cooporate suits who kept standing up and making speeches which annoyed the Brits to no end.  But that's not the restaurants' fault.

This was seriously the best indian dinning experience i'd ever had.  The BF agreed.  The mix of flavors was just right.  The colors mingled on the plate.  There was a balance of creamy, savory, salads, healthy, delicious.  It was like we ordered the perfect combination.
author: Christina C.

description:
Indian Oven has been a bit hit and miss for me...I've ordered the chicken tikka here and it was little bland and too creamy for my tastes and they didn't given me enough chicken.  The naan is a bit soggy and chewy which I'm not a fan of and the prices for everything is a bit on the expensive side for.  I also feel a bit clausterphobic in this restaurant where they pack a lot of people in a very small space and there's hardly any aisle room to move around in.  I went a second time and my friend ordered the Mushroom Matter dish and he absolutely loved it and I ordered the Bhindi Masala (okra dish) and thought it was really good as well so maybe the Vegetarian specialities is where it's at for this restarant???  I'll be back.  Especially since I live in the neighborhood.

3 1/2 stars.
author: LaSha G.

description:
I got some stuff delivered from them, first time, chicken korma, dal soup, saag paneer...  pretty basic, and SUCK SUCK SUCK SUCK SUCK.  I actually had to throw everything out of my apartment because it was stinking the place up like fermented vomit, and left me feeling ill.  

That is all.
author: Max V.

description:
Only a few complaints about this place:

Curry is too watery
Spinach doesn't really blow me away
Making me feel like I should be wearing a black tie is annoying
And stop charging me 10.95 for a basic entree


Otherwise, this is a good spot to take your parents when they're in town-- not very spicy, but definitely is well-made food, and they use pretty decent ingredients.

Don't get the pakora, it's a mess of onions and bullshit.
author: Michael P.

description: This place is awesome.All the food is fresh and has that home made taste.Just arrive early because it will be packed.
author: Big J.

description: The food is definitely excellent...however, the circulation in the restaurant is VERY poor..Unless you do take out..plan to wear your stinkiest cloths there..because it will reak for 3 days afterwards...Not a great place to go on a first or..let's say..the 15th date...just a great place to indulge on good Indian food. I recommend the Saag Paneer and of course the Tandori Chicken... If for some reason you couldn't stand the wait for a table..walk down the street to Rosemunde for a grill sausage instead ;-)
author: Mimi T.

description: Yum!  If you want good, upscale Indian food, this is a great place.  The prices are really reasonable given that the place has white table clothes, a decent wine list and beers on tap.  A great date place!
author: Wendy L.

description: A bit slow on the service. Sat at a table for four against the wall and as with Indian it is always nice to have a bigger table to accomidate the food. the table was small. the food was  slow to get to us and they didn't seem to busy. We did order the basics and it was pretty decent. I would go back but not after a long and hard search for a better Indian option.
author: Chuck G.

description: a few blocks from our house have been coming here for years and we have always had good service, good food - no hick ups and in general been happy with this place.  Food is freshly prepared - unlike some Indian places I've gone to and had stomach issues later.  The best freshly fried dosa's, excellent tandori and great palak paner.  Cannot go wrong with this place!
author: Beth P.

description:
The food was OK but certainly not spectular. The Channa Masala was definitely sub par.  The main dining room was fun but the upstairs had a weird vibe -- specify this in the reservation or you'll be waiting like the rest. 

Big plus for the $18 bottles of red wine and tasty naan.
author: Megan S.

description: Chicken curries were really not good tonight from delivery, very watery. Strange spices not tasty curry hotness.
author: Casey K.

description:
2.5 stars, rounded down cause of the price

Came here with a group, on a thursday night. There front seating was packed, but they extra seating in the back. 

Wait staff seemed kind of disorganized. We ordered appetizers and drinks, and then about 2 minutes later another waiter comes and asks for our drink/appetizer order. Aren't waiters usually assigned tables?

I got the chicken korma, and it was ok. Chicken was on the drier side. Did like that they used yogurt instead of cream, which made the dish much lighter. 

The samosa was pretty tasty, nice spices and all. My onion kulcha looked very different, with all the onion sprinkled on top instead of being incorporated into it.

The papadum and chutney were pretty good. Really liked the mango one. 

I'd say it was on the slightly overpriced side. Overall consensus at the table was about a 6-7 out of 10 for this place. Not sure about the "best in sf" title they have. I think I'd prefer naan n' curry even over this place.
author: Henry L.

description:
Good not great.
I simply think of it as the place Paul sweat.
One night we're there and the food is so so so spicy my friend breaks out into a sweat looking like a 300lb man who's had to hike up the Empire State Building in 20 minutes. 
It was ridiculous, and funny and well, very representative.
You say mild, they say haha and then there you go.
The food is good but its not worth the wait.  
I'd say its better than everything else in the neighborhood but walk over to 16th Street and you'll find much better quality for half the price.
author: Sean S.

description:
Pretty intimate, small place. Casual yet classy at the same time. Great service until it came time to get the check. 

The food was okay; I thought the naan stood out more than anything I ordered. The Goat Cheese Naan and Garlic Naan are very good. I got the Matter Paneer which was pretty bland - no spices at all. My friend got the Lamb Vindaloo and that was pretty tame. If you are not a fan of spicy this is the place for you!

You'll probably spend around $17 - $25 per person if you dine here. Parking is terrible around here but you probably already know that.
author: Johanna C.

description:
We went earlier in the evening during Christmas week, so missed some of the crowds this place is notorious for. Overall, a great dining experience. The food seemed a bit fresher than many of the Indian places around town, and the service was certainly a bit friendlier than Shalimar, which seems to be a crowd favorite for some god-forsaken reason.

In any case, I liked Indian Oven. I'd definitely go back, or perhaps pick it up to-go on a busy night.
author: Chris B.

description:
Love this place.  I moved into my new apartment September 1st and just when I thought my life couldn't possibly get any better, I discovered Indian Oven on the corner.  

The dishes and naan are amazing.  Their lamb holds flavor well while remaining fork tender and the veggie dishes are cooked to crunchy yet tender perfection.  For staples, their chicken tikka masala is superb.  The sauce is spicy and the chicken retains an incredible smokiness that rocks.  I've been in my new apartment for two weeks and I've eaten here twice already.  I'm going to be in trouble.

When I called for take out they actually asked me how I liked my veggies cooked for the korma.  "A little undercooked?", he asked. Pretty sweet.

Let the menu tour begin.  After reading other postings, the goat cheese naan is next on my list.  And Kingfisher beer? It'll be a Goan holdiay round two in Lower Haight.
author: Corey F.

description: My prawn dish had a slightly foul taste to it, but what can you do when it's 3pm and you're starving?  When the check arrived, there was a charge of $5.90 for two 'pulao's.  What is this, I thought?  I asked about it, and the waiter said it was the rice.  I mean, if you're going to nickel and dime over rice, it better be worth $6.  You just made $6, but you just got a lower rating, so you surely lost more than that.  No, they did not tell me that rice would be extra.
author: Won L.

description: So far this is my favorite Indian place in the Lower Haight. I can't get enough of the Dal Soup, it is so tasty! All the dishes I have had have been great. The service is also excellent.
author: Leo V.

description: My husband and I are new to Indian food, but found the food quite fresh and flavorful. So much so that we ate there 2 weeks in a row. We enjoyed the chicken tikka masala and the tandoori chicken - and of course the hot naan. We also enjoyed the open, airy feeling of the restaurant and the colorful artwork that adorns the walls.
author: Adrienne L.

description:
Hi! We went here last night.  The busboy was warmer and friendlier then
the waiter.  The sauces on the table were good and went with the
complimentary wafer.  The onion kulcha was good.  The entree"s came
and the lamb korma was tender but a tiny portion.  The saag paneer, which i always order at indian restaurants, was salty.  The owner refilled my wine with a better wine then my original choice at no extra cost, which was good.  Our tab altogether came to $65, not worth it.
author: lisa v.

description: It was pretty good. Nice interior and friendly staff. Wasn't overall impressed with my portion size, until about fifteen minutes later when I couldn't force myself to eat anymore and I still had masala left.
author: Alex R.

description:
Even thought the reviews are mixed, the two times I have been here, I found great food.  A wonderful place if you want to take a date.  The samosas were great, the curries were good, and even the rice pudding was good.  The problems here is that it is a little expensive and I believe it is inconsistant....but I would say worth the price for a date.  Really clean, and good service.  

A friend of mine who agrees with my other Indian food reccomendations was not impressed.  That leads me to believe that there can be good times here and bad ones...
author: Kapeli M.

description:
I was craving Indian food and my friend picked this place since it's her favorite.  It was my first time and I was completely impressed.

First off - it's nice inside...like open and clean and and nice...unlike most other indian restaurants in the city.  And the wine is cheap !!

We had the tikka masala, korma, naan, raita...and everything was amazing.  we pretty much cleaned up.  Service was awesome - we never had empty glasses over water and our food was brought at a comfortable place.

plus we found a sweet parking spot which made it all the better!

yum!
author: Lauren V.

description:
OVEN.
This place is so great, I now consider Indian food from Indian Oven to be my comfort food.
Not greasy, everything I've has was great. Paneer Tika Korma & some garlic naan is unbeatable.
Nicest waiters, fun atmosphere- everyone always seems happy to be here. there's a room up in the back that's better for larger groups. The wait has gotten much shorter in recent years, which is good for us, not so good for them. But I'm delighted to have less people fighting to get in this yummy spot..
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
Definitely the best within two blocks, but you'll pay for it.  If only they had a lunchtime buffet...

Excellent service and we usually have some left to take home.  Great chutneys.
author: Amy C.

description:
I thought that the food was bad ass.  Apparently I may be the only person outside of the south that likes okra, but damn, this place rocks the okra like nobodies business!!!  
Sooo good, the samosas were awesome, tika masala was yummy and the garlic naan so good.  I will for sure be back and the waiters were on it like white on rice!   I know we ordered more items, yet this is what stuck out in my mind.
author: Nicole F.

description:
food: five stars (* * * * *)
Now, I'll readily admit I haven't had too much Indian in my life (perhaps 15-20 times), but this was hands-down the best I have ever had.  The boyfriend and I dined on Chicken Tikka Masala, a benchmark dish at any Indian establishment, in my opinion.  The chicken, tender.  The sauce, so unbelievably flavorful and rich--without being too heavy--we were literally scrapping every last bit of naan to get it off the plate.  We also ordered the Saag Gosht, which is boneless lamb in a creamed spinach sauce.  If you like lamb, for the love of God order this dish, it was mind-blowingly tasty and full of flavor.  Of course, fresh-out-of-the-oven naan and basmati rice accompanied the meal.

environment/service: four stars (* * * *)
The environment is cosy and we had a seat by the window, looking out on Fillmore.  Maneuvering inside the restaurant proved to be a slight challenge due to tight spaces but aside from that, the service was prompt and friendly.

value: four stars (* * * *)
Everything was reasonable but compared to other Indian restaurants, not particularly cheap.  Each dish was around $13 and the naan and basmati rice were $2 each (we ordered two orders of naan, no explanations necessary on that).  A glass of Riesling accompanied the meal and I have to give them kudos for not ass-raping their patrons on a glass of wine.  A respectable $6 for a glass is a great bargain.  The total came to $50 for two people.

average of
food: five stars
environment/service: four stars
value: four stars
================
averaged grand total: four stars

estimated price per person (excluding drink):
$20-25

would i recommend it to others?
Yes, definitely.

would i return?
Yes.
author: Benjamin L.

description: Update, I wrote my original review on 1/28, the next day someone from Indian Oven called me.  I had ordered through Eat24 hours so they had my number so I was ok with the call though it's a bit out of the norm.  An employee there was very apologetic and said that Yelp reviews matter a great deal to them as does customer satisfaction.  He said that the food had been ordered as mild.  I know this was not the case but whether this is a glitch w Eat24 or Indian Oven I don't know.  He asked if they could send me more food again and if I would revise my opinion.  I told them I wasn't interested in eating Indian Oven twice in a row.  I asked instead for a gift certificate for the value of my order.  That I would attend the restaurant in person anonymously and try it again to see if it was improved.  I'm now moving my review from 1 to 3 stars simply due to their effort in correcting things.  I'll update again after I eat there.
author: Noel C.

description:
I was craving Indian food badly tonight.
So much so that I pulled up yelp as I was driving to see which Indian restaurants were closest to pick up take-out on my drive home.  I was near Lower Haight  and Indian Oven came up (along with others).  I pulled up the website (I pulled over first) and was impressed with all of the awards for "best Indian food" year after year.  
I ordered Chicken Tikka Masala (not very original I know) and a side order of rice.
When I got home I opened the food and it was like no Tikka Masala I had ever seen.  Super watery thin sauce (no thick sauce like normal) and just big chunks of chicken and maybe 5 tiny diced pieces of tomato.  I am used to almost a gravy with onions and tomatoes along with chicken.  This looked like someone cut up a chicken breast and threw it in a thin tomato juice/milk mixture.
The rice was really good but come on, it's rice.
This place disappointed me tonight, and it definitely didn't fulfill my craving!
author: Alisa M.

description: The food here is really great quality, but the portions are fairly small, especially when ordered delivery. The naan is fresh and chewy, the curries thick and aromatic, and the meats flavorful and juicy.  So far the best Indian I have tried on this side of town.
author: Brittany T.

description: Just as good as it ever was. Changed owners a while back, and we were worried it would take a turn for the worse. But after an initial bedding-in phase it's back to being the best wee Indian spot in the city. Geat value, Kingfisher on tap (!), good quick service and best of all, absolutely top food. For any of you old timers that have given it a wide berth recently, pop back in and see for yourself.
author: Alan C.

description:
While this place delivers a more upscale atmosphere in comparison to its Indian food neighbors, the food itself is sub par.  It has a lot of the pedestrian dishes that we Indian-foodies have all come to love, but at an enormous cost.. if this were a cheapie I would love it - but its downright pricey for the quality, portions etc.. it all just feels a bit dishonest.

PS if you do eat here - do not order the dal soup.  It IS the most watery and bland dal I have ever had in an Indian restaurant.  I am a big dal fan, and not a big dal snob.  I am very surprised they even serve it as it was...
author: Zachary K.

description: My family and I have been coming here for over 15 years and considered it the benchmark of good Indian food.  When friends would visit from out of town, this was a mainstay.  Yesterday was a HUGE disappointment.  Our waiter was not friendly, and that would have been gladly overlooked if the food was what we expected but it fell far, far below our lowest standards.  The samosas must have been pre-made.  The inside was like mush.  No ingredient was discernable. The naan was fairly good, but the lamb vindaloo, the chicken tikka masala, even the rice were tasteless.  We even sent back the saag mushroom, as it looked like it had been sitting under a warmer all day and had zero taste.  I can't believe I'm saying this, but we won't be coming back to Indian Oven.
author: Heather L.

description: Since they have changed ownership they have gone downhill in food and service. I ordered chicken korma and got dark meat when the menu said it was a white meat dish. Service is slow when it's not even busy. I miss the previous owners.
author: Mama S.

description:
So worth the trip and the wait.

Every dish is great and the staff is attentive without being overbearing.  They could give you a little more room at the table...but with food this good, you cant really complain.
author: Ken S.

description:
I heart this joint. I heart this place very much. probably the best Indian Restaurant in SF (and for the love of god, order the rice pudding...it will rock your world.)

However, here is my major issue with this place -- It seems to be closed...can somebody please tell me what's going on? I'm moving in a couple months and I'm starting to panic.
author: Devin D.

description:
Need an Indian restaurant that serves *awesome* food and doesn't suffer from garish decor?

Indian Oven is one of the best Indian restaurants in the Bay Area. It's not cheap, but the food is fantabulous! It's been a while, so I won't comment on specific dishes, but I remember being happy with everything I ordered there.

And unlike most Indian restaurants, this establishment's not covered in red and gold decor. It's actually pretty yuppified, white linens and all -- and added bonus if you're looking for a "nice place" in addition to great food.
author: Joyce S.

description:
This place is definitely a solid Indian restaurant.  It's nice inside and service is pleasant.  The food, I thought, is very tasty - chicken across the board tends to be excellent and tender (I tend to find that a lot of Indian places have great sauces and then the meet is fatty and not so good).  And I know this may be slight more expensive then curry in a hurry type places but I think to say it's overpriced is crazy!  They have $14 BOTTLES of wine people.  I mean, that alone, in my opinion is reason to go.  Literally their wine is half the price I see on other menus.  I don't normally order wine with Indian (I prefer beer) but when I saw that I had to.  We also didn't finish it so we proceeded to march our bottle out of the restaurant to take home and no one stopped us (we weren't sure if this is allowed in cali).  Now that's chill lower haight lovin'.

I consistently leave this place fat and happy and having shared a bottle of wine for about $25 a person.  Maybe I'm jaded from nyc but I think that's a damn good deal.
author: Katie M.

description:
This is some of the most finessed and best done Indian restaurants in the city.  

The preparation is consistent , and they are not afraid to turn up the spicy heat. HOT!, No literally, really HOT!

The downside, crowds, go early or don't go at all.
author: Ken p.

description:
Yum, yum, yum.  I love India Oven.  It never disappoints.  We ordered garlic naan, prawn vindaloo, chicken tikka masala, and a vegetable dish with spinach and potatoes.  All were great.  Even the newbie I brought with me to eat at this place, who has only eaten Indian food once and wasn't too keen on it, loved this place. 

All I can say is...Indian Oven trumps anything I've ever had in So Cal. If only the parking wasn't so screwed up around there!
author: Angie K.

description:
This place is roomy,  friendly, and attentive. Overall, the food was very good. I had the  scrumptious Saag Aloo with some naan and rice.

The spot is handicap accessible... sorta. When I went there was a huge booth seat blocking the front door. They moved it right away as soon as they saw that I was approaching with my chair; however, if that seat had been occupied for the way in and leaving... it would have been a big hassle for those seated at that spot.

There is no handicap accessbile way to the upstairs portion of the restaurant unless you have a chaperone willing to assist in pulling you up and and slowly lowering you down the tiny steps.
author: Anita J.

description:
Curry Goodness....

Indian oven is one of my favorite Indian restaurants in the city!

The naan is amazing definitely try the goat cheese. I'm also a big fan of the saag paneer, chicken tikka masala and raita. 

This place can get busy too so I'd make reservations.
author: Summer C.

description:
like, i know this is supposed to be a really good indian food joint but...it's just not that special.

chicken byriani...boring, fatty chicken (pet peeve), garlic naan is good, goat cheese naan is weird.

fast delivery though, that's a bonus. i mean, i'd just rather... not.
author: Emily I.

description:
Went with one friend and definitely have to go back with more people. We ordered so many dishes because we couldn't decide what sounded the best. Everything we had was awesome- it was a while back so I'm not sure of the names of everything we had. I know we had some big meat skewer plate, garlic naan and the yogurt sauce that's like tzatziki, chicken and rice, and maybe lamb saag.

Awesome, can't wait to go back!
author: Diane S.

description:
The Indian Oven is like a really good movie with too much hype you fortunately never heard about.  It's great to go there, maybe on a blind date with no expectations, you're gonna see a movie afterwards, probably something bad, and it happens to be a day/time when the wait isn't catastrophic.  The food will be very good and you may hear yourself proclaim it, "the best you've had in San Francisco."

But, as many have realized, if you go expecting some miricle beyond the abilities of copious amounts cream and oil, AND you waited for an hour for a table in a crowded little square space, then you may proclaim, "This is the most overrated Indian food in the city."

Timing is everything.
author: J. Scott H.

description:
I loved it here.  Quite possibly the best Indian food I've ever had.

There seems to be some folks who greatly disagree, saying the food isn't that great... In that case, I'd love to try the places they recommend, because if the food is _better_ than Indian oven, it's gotta be phenomenal.

I loved the food at Indian oven and I'll definitely be going back.
author: Joshua E.

description:
For this price, it's not really that great.
Pakwan is much better and cheaper.
author: Bobby T.

description:
Decent Indian food.  Had chicken vindaloo, tikka masala, saag aloo and garlic naan.  For the price, I don't think there was enough meat in the dishes.  We specified spicy for the vindaloo, but it wasn't very spicy and kind of watery.  The saag aloo was tasty, though.  

The tables are really close together, so it was difficult to squeeze into our seats.  The food came out superfast, though.  Our bill (after tax and tip) was $60, for three curries, three naans and one beer.  A little too pricey for the quality of food.  Especially, when at other Indian restaurants in this price range, you get free papadums.
author: Jory R.

description:
Best Indian food in San Francisco. My husband and I never miss an opportunity to dine here when we travel to San Francisco - we plan trips around it. 

We judge most indian restaurants by the sag paneer. Here, it's perfectly creamy and spicey without an overwhelming spice. The cheese cubes are the perfect texture. The samosa are perfectly cooked with plenty of vegetables, chicken korma rich and buttery, the rice is light and fluffy and flavorful, lamb vindaloo (very hot) is hot and delicious. Service is excellent and prompt. It's always packed so we do recommend reservations. Well worth a trip across town if necessary. Good for groups - but only if you make a reservation!

We highly recommend this place.
author: ET K.

description:
OK, so I finally took Norman up on his offer and called him up to let him know my husband and I wanted to come into the restaurant to try it out. This was a Weds night and first thing I noticed the place had a  warm and cozy feel.  Then I took note that the place was about 3/4 full.  After being seated immediately I asked our waiter to let Norman know I had arrived.  5 minutes later we were very kindly greeted by Norman and I must say his attention to us and service his staff displayed were outstanding. 

 We ordered the Papdum to start.  Nice flavor.  Shortly thereafter we were presented with 2 samosas which we did not order.  Very nice.  Complements of the house.  Our main entrees were the fish tandoori, full order of tandoori chicken and the lamb jaffrezi.  OMG, the fish tandoori melted in my mouth.  The sea bass was cooked perfectly and had a smoky taste.  The tandoori chicken was exceptionally moist.  The lamb was tender.  To end the meal Norman sent over an indian dessert for us.  Very nice.  The full order of the tandoori was huge and we ended up taking most of our food home.  

All in all this place did not disappoint.  The food, atmosphere and service top notch.  A far cry from my NYE experience.  We will be back again and again.   Norman put his $ where his mouth was and was very generous.  Thanks Norman for being passionate about your business.  It shows!
author: A H.

description: Amazing food. Quick service and generous portions.  Lamb korma was heavenly!! Extremely extensive menu and great service for a good price.  Highly suggest hitting 3 Twins across the street after for dessert...
author: Betsy C.

description: Few Indian restaurants are able to teeter between romantic and just plain dirty. It's usually one or the other (expensive and posh, or cheap and gross)  but some days it's not always about the price (though I will say it is nice to see wines by the glass at $5). Tuesday night it was about the overall experience and mood paired with  delicious food  and a warm caring hand across the white linen table cloth. A  red Zin, a mixed appetizer platter and a hand that made my heart smile. What else could you ask for out of a date? Indian oven surprised  us with a complimentary rice pudding :)
author: Michelle K.

description:
Enjoy their food but do not use use GrubHub for these guys. 

1+ hour late and we are still waiting. Unacceptable.

They say they're sending desert as an apology, but that doesn't cut it after we have been waiting for 1.5 hours.
author: Carey V.

description:
While the service is decent and the atmosphere is nice, but the food is very unimpressive. We got chicken tikka masala, saag paneer, rice and naan. The chicken was "barbecued" and then the sauce was clearly added afterward. The result was a very odd combination of smoky chicken with your average tikka masala sauce. It was a very odd combination of flavors and it just clashed rather than going together.

The saag paneer was bland and the textures were terrible. The spinach (saag) was very solid, as in not saucy like it should be but just boring overcooked spinach. The texture of the paneer was worse, kind of rubbery and not creamy or rich like it should be. Very disappointing.

The naan was good, so that's what got it up to 2 stars.
author: John B.

description:
I had been to this place some time back and yesterday we went there again. It was raining outside and the restaurant was warm from inside. The ambience is pretty good and so is the food. We read in other reviews that the food was less spicy and hence we ordered to make the Mutter Paneer and Dal Fry as spicy and that came as a little more spicy than expected. So the best thing I would suggest, is have them prepared as they do in their regular style (so that they do not mess up) and ask them for a separate spicy sauce (so that you can add as per your taste)

The papadum was very crispy. Parking os a definitely a problem here (this is a problem everywhere in SF)

Overall I would give this as a 3 star.
author: Hemant P.

description:
I like the atmosphere, the inside of the restaurant is nice, servers are nice even with the mariachi band vests. But the food? Eeeanhh. We've been twice with groups of people and everything is underwhelming. 

For instance last time I ordered Navratan Korma which they describe as "Mixed vegetables in a delicately spiced cream sauce and cashew nuts" I think Navartan means nine-gems so its nine nuts fruits and vegetables in a cream sauce. It's pretty flexible but was one of my favorite dishes in India and you can find great recipes online, like on YouTube by Manjula -- yummm. But this version was distinguished by paneer, peas, pineapple and pinenuts (instead of cashews)  floating in thin milky sauce. Also lima-like beans that were in a lot of the dishes that evening, although I don't  associate any of those dishes with lima beans.

 I'd always heard great things about this place so I might return again to see if I just didn't hit it right but I'm not too tempted.
author: jen n.

description: I had the palaak paneer and veggie biryani... decent, but definitely not the "best" as some people seem to have put it.  Nice atmosphere, good service.
author: Peter N.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet. I love this place.  I live in the neighborhood and eat here about once a week. The staff and food are top notch and the space itself has nice high ceilings and great natural light.  It's very authentic.
author: Clare C.

description: Quick, easy, yummy! Great service! 4 stars.
author: Sean H.

description: Amazing! I loved the okra and the cheese dish.... and the garlic nann. The rice pudding was a wow, oh and the mango drink very tasty. I'm not good with names, but everything was excellent!
author: Madigan M.

description:
for the most exciting combinations of flavors served in a fresh and inspired way...check out the Indian Oven.
BEST indian food in the city...and beyond.
author: stella s.

description:
BEST INDIAN FOOD EVER!  This place was introduced to me by two Scottish friends who are Indian food fanatics.  They swore that it was the best in town so I tried it out.  And of course, I found that the food was excellent.  Each dish has a unique flavor, whereas other places I've tried seem to have dishes that kinda all taste the same.  The meats are tender and flavorful, and the sauces are spiced just right.  

This place is CLEAN, elegant, has great ambience, and the service is fantastic.  My favorite dishes are Chicken Korma, Aloo Gobhi, Saag Paneer, and Lamb Pasanda, which are all on the mild-spice side.  I am not a big fan of super spicy foods, so Indian Oven's large selection of mild and creamy/saucy dishes really appeals to me.  You can get super spicy dishes there, but I just prefer the milds, which are just as flavorful as the spicy dishes.  

The dishes are on the smaller side, so I'd say for 3 people order about 4 dishes and share.  Their rice is delicious and has whole cloves and cardamom in it to spice.  Their naan is great and they are the only place that has a sampler dish with various types of naan to try.  Indian Oven is the best Indian food in town, so try it out!  They even take reservations!  LOVE IT.
author: K N.

description: Good Indian food at a good price,Loved the chicken Tikka Masala .Best indian restauarant in the town
author: Raju N.

description:
Indian Oven is back!! 

The negative comment someone wrote about the new ownership is not accurate, in my opinion. In fact, it is the new owners that have made some excellent and much-needed changes....and in just the first two weeks.

For starters, the bathroom is now sparkling clean and smells great. This was a nontrivial problem for years that is now gone.

Also, the service is now well-paced. It used to be WAY too quick - so much so that it really ruined the meal experience. They have also added nice little touches, like free papadum with dipping sauces when you are seated. 

Awesome!

The wait staff also seem happier. I know it's weird to note, but the old staff just seemed miserable and they really brought down the experience of being there. Not anymore. On our last visit, the servers were upbeat and focused. The result is that the service was just right - attentive, pleasant, well-paced, and not overbearing.

In my estimation, the food quality has kept Indian Oven in business over the years. The food really is excellent. On our most recent visit, my girlfriend and I started with the samosas and then had chana masala and, of course, the lamb korma. As always, the dishes are the most reliable and the most delicious in town. 

Never had a bad meal here in over ten years. The recipes are solid.

I like that they added Kingfisher on draft. It's not the world's greatest beer, but having it on draft brings out a flavor that you just can't get in the bottle. It's encouraging that the new owners are thinking about details like this.

I was worried for a while that Indian Oven was in trouble, and I think it was. But, the new owners are considering the entire dining experience from top to bottom; and it definitely shows. They have made an immediate and noticeable difference and have brought up the level of service so that it now matches the high quality of the food.

It's amazing what concerned and aware owners can do to transform a venue.

A++, Indian Oven. You are better than ever.

Welcome back!!!
author: D B.

description: Pretty basic Indian experience. Friendly service. Took four entrees to experiment this place and they all tasted quite the same. Weird.
author: Jari S.

description:
Extraordinarily spiced dishes with a unique twist.

I was truly blown away with our meal the other night. As a self proclaimed Indian food connoisseur, this place has all the right things going for it. From the welcoming Nepalese staff to the smokey taste of their korma sauce, I simmered in the savory evening. 

Indeed, this is a "higher end" Indian restaurant, but there's no Dosa stick up its butt. (I love Dosa, but lets be real, it has a different vibe.) Indian Oven is warm, courteous  and mellow. 
Our party of 4 sat in the back room where it was a bit quieter and less sceney. We loved the 3 sauces and pickled veggies that came with the papadums - nice and full of flavor. The samosas were legit, crispy & filled with goodness, and paired perfectly with the sauces too. We shared 5 entrees, but probably only needed 4. However, that's what Indian at a restaurant is all about, sharing with a good group of peeps. We had the paneer korma and chicken korma, which was some of the best, most unique korma I have ever tasted. It had a smokey taste to it, almost chipotle-like, and richly delicious. I'm usually not a fan of paneer, as cheese doesn't seem to go with Indian seamlessly. However, this was awesome paneer and to boot, they had a goat cheese naan. It was an Indian quesadilla, unique and good. 
We LOVED the fish tikka masala, it came out buttery and spicy. The saag aloo was awesome and hearty with great spices too. The lamb vindaloo was the only dish I wouldn't order again though, it just lacked moisture and good texture.

My other favorite thing was the rice pudding desert. I haven't had legit rice pudding since my days in the 'Desh. Milky, rich and sweetly spiced. 

Overall, it was simply amazing and I will certainly be returning soon. 

Well done IO, bhalo, khub bhalo.
author: Erin M.

description: The food has gone downhill a lot in the last two years.  DIshes are much less deftly balanced these days, and the quality no longer justifies the (slight) premium they charge.
author: David B.

description: Indian Oven is by far my most favorite Indian restaurant in the city by far. The food is superb! U must try all the sea bass dishes they have. Fish Masala, Fish salad, and one other I cant remember. Either way look for them. Also everything else I have tried on the menu is great, I've never had a bad dish. The goat cheese Naan is awesome too! Basically, if you don't like this place, you don't like Indian.
author: Ethan S.

description: Oh no! Something's happened to the Indian Oven, and it's not something good. The last two times we were there, the food wasn't nearly as good--the sauces were watery and bland. Hopefully this isn't a permanent change, and the quality will snap back?
author: Elle C.

description:
A good friend of mine brought me here after RAVING about this place.

I gotta say, they get points for atmosphere.  I find that most Indian places seem to get decorated by the same folks: it's always kinda empty, linen table clothes with the usual decor.  This place was unusual in that it felt just like any other lively restaurant- they just were serving Naan and curries instead of linguini w/ crab sauce.

Anyhow, yeah the food here is good. I definitely enjoyed the Saag gosht(spinach w/lamb) and the poori!  The lamb was super tender and the creme spinach was flavorful.  I was super excited to see they had the poori here. I find that to be kinda rare.  You get 2 big ones for $3! Rice was not included however and apparently the portions are small. There were 5 of us, and we got 2 orders, which came on one small plate....so we had to order more.  I liked that the rice was flavored w/ safron and had peas in it, but it was a little underdone.  I didn't get to try the naan, but I noticed that 1 order of naan is a small basket with maybe 5 square pieces. The entree portions are also a little small...considering that rice is separate.  A friend ordered the Chicken Korma, which I snagged a bite from...very good. chicken might have been  a little dry.

The service was very attentive and friendly.  Bathrooms were clean and smelled really good!!

Overall I'd say that the food is very good.  I think that it's comparable to most of the better indian places I have been too. The thing that really sets it apart is the ambiance.  

Oh yeah, be warned: parking is a bitch in this part of town!!!
author: Chris B.

description:
By far this is my favorite Indian restaurant in the city!  Even when I lived other places and made trips back to SF, I definitely had to stop here as one of my destination places.  

It's the only place outside of England that I feel has the best Chicken Tikka Masala...

Parking is an absolute nightmare, so I highly recommend ordering take-out and double parking while you pick up.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: Hey, I still love this place.  It's crazy though how the business has waned particularly over the past 2 years.  I've been coming here for 10 years too.  It used to be that you wouldn't be able to get in prime time Fri/Sat nights without waiting for 45 minutes in the cold with your name on a clipboard outside.  Now you can go anytime and there's no wait.  I don't see that the food has gotten worse (Yay Chicken Makhani - not on the menu, but an amazing curry.  Butter Chicken.  Mix between korma and tike masala).  The only thing that's not consistently good is the naan.  It can be cracker thin and crispy which I don't like.  I even walked around to see if Clay Oven, Naan and Curry, or Roti is just such a great value that ppl are not coming here anymore and didn't see those places crowded or their menu super compelling.  Anyway, still love this place!
author: Deal G.

description: The food was good but the service left something to be desired. We waited for about 15 minutes just to order. They poured water for 3 out of 4 of us and it took another 10 minutes to get water for the 4th person in our party. At the end of dinner they didn't ask us if we wanted dessert before bringing us the check (which we had to wait for another 15 min to get after finishing our main courses). *sigh*
author: Yael H.

description: I took my boyfriends parents here who were pretty new to Indian food. When we first walked in, I thought it was going to be a bit expensive, but it ended up being not much more than normal Indian food. Our waiter was very helpful and our water glasses were always full (which was a blessing considering the spiciness of some of our dishes). We all enjoyed our dishes and plan to go back this weekend!
author: Bridget D.

description: Do not, repeat, do not be fooled by the popularity of this place. For some reason, San Franciscans, while claiming to be original, are certainly not adventurous. The Indian place across the street is far better in quality and authenticity, and you don't have to wait half an hour for a table.
author: Nish N.

description:
First of all, you should know that these Yelp reviews are written by an insane person. In L & O speak (I was a hardcore L & O fan for 5 years and I still kind of am, I mostly watch SVU to stare at Mariska Hargitay and I watch CI to stare and imagine my future life with Vincent D'Onofrio (if either of you are reading this, I will drop everything to be with either of you. But ideally, both of you together. Does anyone have any Dick Wolf connections? Let's make this happen), it can be said I am under extreme emotional duress.  Blah blah boyproblem cakes. Let's move on, shall we!? 

And when the lady comes into extreme emotional duress, few things hit the spot than a nice dose of Indian food. I hate every other Indian restaurant in this area so I figured I'd give this place a shot. And the verdict is that I felt leaving a little more emotionally fucked with since I'd been led to believe that this place was omg best Indian ever and omg, it so wasn't. Lahore Kahari is better. Tasty Curry is better. Fuck, even delivery from outer richmond buffet palaces Great India & India Clay Oven is... that's right, you guessed it, better. This food is perfectly decent but very overpriced and the curries were watery and it was just so safe and so boring and like going out with that nice boy with the nice job who thinks he's so edgy because he saw the roots perform at his liberal arts college and he took a women's studies class instead of the crazy fucked up coroner with the motorcycle who will ditch you to go play D & D. Or the video game tester with a particular penchant for hosiery and um...other things I will not go into. And knowing me, I always pick the crazy fucked up dude. Soooo... I'm sticking with filthy Indian places. That's my story. See - this review made no sense. Insanity rules.  Indian Oven : C+. Exploiting my experiences for "comedic effect": A +
author: Maria D.

description: I am not much of an Indian food guy, but I would say this was just a little above average food. It was a nicer place with decent food. Our server was a little awkward and seemed very confused.
author: Jeff H.

description: I have to say, I am surprised to see all the two and three-star reviews of this place.  I have tried a lot of indian restaurants in San Francisco and elsewhere, and this is the best one I've ever been to.  Must-try dishes include the creamy, buttery chicken korma, tangy chicken tikka masala, lamb saag, pretty much all the dishes are excellent here.  You can't go wrong. Make sure to put down a nice bed of safron rice to soak up all the delicious flavors and spices of the sauces and then ladel plenty of raitha onto all of your dishes.  Simply the best.
author: Rick H.

description: the food didn't taste bad, but was watered down and artificial seeming in color and texture- definitively curry powder-tastic. will not return, but better than some other Indian places. I don't understand how this place is so well reviewed.
author: Liz S.

description: This is white breed Indian cuisine. You go here for the ambience and not the fantastic food albeit the food is decent, but it's nothing special. The ambience though is like you went over to a friend's parent's house for dinner and they just whipped up something for you to satisfy your hunger and not your palette.
author: Sherry C.

description: For this money? Ugh! This place is probably the most overrated Indian restaurant in SF. The food isn't bad but I can get better Indian food at any number of places in the Tenderloin and not wait so I can be crammed into a small dining room like a not-so-sacred cow.
author: patrick g.

description: Delightful little place with impeccable service wearing super cool black vests.  The lamb is exquisite so get over your moral discomfort and tuck in.  I also recommend all the little serving sauces but you will get dirty looks when you pick up the table display of mango chutney and chug it down.  FYI Yelpers...
author: Johnny G.

description: I dunno man.  Maybe i just don't know what good Indian food is and how to distinguish a high quality vindaloo from crap vindaloo, but it seems to me that when I came here I just paid 40 bucks for a meal i could have easily gotten for 15 at naan and curry.  That is all.
author: William S.

description: I've been here many times in the past and I've found so many other places that are much better and half the price.  This place to me was great a few years ago but another place around the corner is much better and a lot less crowded.
author: Mitch A.

description: Would you trust the boy that mistook cheese for chicken to give this opinion credence?
author: Marc M.

description: It'd be nice if I could actually review this place. Unfortunately, even with our name on the "list" we literally waited outside (in the cold) for 45 minutes. No one came to check on us or ask us if we wanted a drink. We checked again, they told us it'd be another 30 minutes. HA! What a joke. Instead we went down the street to Rotee and had a decent meal at a much more reasonable price. Indian Oven really needs to pay more attention to the huge lines outside of their establishment as there are too many Indian restaurants to choose from to be so careless...
author: Nicolas H.

description: SO good. If you want really good Indian, this is the place. Don't get it to go though. The containers aren't meant to travel and the food will be all over your lap before you get home with it.
author: michelle k.

description: Wonderful smells constantly emanate from this place and I've been anxious to try the cuisine. I have to say I wasn't disappointed. We went in with a big group and ordered up family style. Everything was tasty in my opinion, granted I'm a white kid from Wisconsin, but I thought it was quite savory. Delicious Bengan Pakoras, Chicken Tika Masala and Bengan Bartha. Refills on drinks were a little hard to get, but I can overlook that.
author: Michael E.

description: My husband and I skip the wait and bring dinner home from Indian Oven at least twice a month. The Fish Masala (chilean sea bass in tomoato curry sauce) is generally my go-to, but is quickly being overshadowed by some of the amazing vegetarian sides like Chana Masala (garbanzo beans cooked with onions and fresh tomatoes), Aloo Gobhi (cauliflower and potatoes cooked with a hint of garlic), and the Saag Mushroom (mushroom and spinach cooked with spices).  Perfect on a cold night with a bottle of Shiraz and a movie.
author: Julie B.

description: a little disappointed.  the food quality was not up to par with the $$ I spent per dish.  i've had better indian food in mall food courts.
author: Mike C.

description: $#!t fcuk  crap bee@ch fat fcuk..the owner is a mofo..avoid
author: Rasta R.

description: This place is great for a good comforting Indian meal. Sure, it's more expensive than some Indian restaurants, and of course it's more crowded, but that's what one would expect if something is this good!
author: Michelle B.

description: I think I missed out on what the big deal is.  I don't mind paying $50 for dinner (including two glasses of wine) with the husband, but honestly, it just wasn't that great.
author: Nat K.

description:
i always want to like this place because its location, pleasant atmosphere and good reviews, but i never do. nothing is everyvery flavorful or spicy and it's not priced to be a hole in the wall indian place so i expect it to be a lot better.

the spinach paratha was salty to the extreme and full of sand -ouch- they need a salad spinner! 

the pakora are cakey.
author: Sophia L.

description: One of the best Indian restaurants in town, when you can afford to splurge a little money.  The hot-baked bread is delicious, and the spices are terrific.
author: Paul H.

description: Given the consistent fabulous reviews, I came hoping for the best, but came out really disappointed (though it was fun sitting next to Danny Glover).  I re-read the reviews and was sure I had a bad night.  Back the second time, and another dissappointment.  Flat flavors reminded me of Indian food from the mall I had as a teenager.
author: nick w.

description: It works, but they got started about at least uh 15 years ago ? when there were very few Indian restaurants in the city. The new century brought the incredible increase in Indian/Pakistani eateries throughout the Bay Area and the bay is their oyster oven so to speak.
author: miriam b.

description: Why are people not giving this place 5 stars?!? The food is great, with great bang for your buck, and the place has a cozy feel (though maybe too cozy if it's packed. I went with a couple of friends, including one who is Indian, and we all loved it. If you're anywhere near the Lower Haight, go here. Just make sure to make reservations on a weekend night.
author: Alexi S.

description: I enjoyed everything I sampled, and since there were a group of us I tasted a lot.  The fish was tasty and not over cooked.  The fresh mango juice was so good I wanted to ask for a to-go cup.  The food could have been seasoned a little better, but overall I have no complaints.  I will be back!
author: Jay L.

description:
This place is a disgrace. 

Lets start with the food. Many of the dishes are watery thin, which is dissatisfying when eaten with naan (see all the other reviewers below that confirm this). Its as if they try to extend the kitchen's output to many customers by just adding water. Unethical, and just plain stupid. 

The tables are packed so tight, you WILL feel cramped and uncomfortable no matter where you sit. Its like chickens in a coop. Some of the chairs as just impossible to get to, unless you get on tiptoe and scrape your ass past someone else's table while they eat. It's not like this is done because the place is in such popular demand - it clearly feels like the idea was to maximize the number of diners per unit area. 

Ah yes, finally, the price. This is the kind of restaurant that uses having white tablecloths as an excuse to justify adding 30-50% more to each dish's price. If the taste was good, one could swallow these prices. Here, it just sticks out as another example of the owner's greedy efforts to squeeze profits out of the wallets of unwitting customers (at least once before they get wiser). Hopefully they will read these reviews and avoid even that one time.

Oh by the way, the most interesting thing about the much raved about goat cheese naan is.... you guessed it, the novelty and the price ($5), but alas, not the taste.

Nish N and Sav B's reviews of this place are also right on the mark, and also solve the mystery of why this place manages to get inexplicably high reviews.
author: Shwin S.

description: The place across the street has tiny portions. I will always love the Indian Oven!
author: Beth V.

description: I think Indian Oven is over-rated, but still pretty good.  One of the most expensive Indian places in the area. Their chicken korma is killer, though.
author: katie p.

description:
Pleasant atmosphere; abysmal service. After waiting for an hour for our food with no updates from the server, we walked out. 

Change of ownership seems to be at fault, according to a recent post; unfortunately, this seems to be for the worse (or worst, in this case).
author: Amanda D.

description:
despite all the fanfare and lines i see of people outside of the door, i was was totally uninspired by the food. this muse ain't singing nothing for this place.

it was also crazy expensive and the portions weren't all that big. yeah it's fancy inside bla bla bla, but was rather low on the deliciousness scale.

i'd rather go back to pakwan. it's cheaper and better.
author: monkey l.

description: The food's okay, not the best Indian food I've ever had though.  The wait is insane.  I usually go right when they open...I hate lines.  The service is good when you're early but mediocre the later it gets.  BEWARE...They ask how spicy you want it, if you say mild it's super mild but medium is what most people would call hot.  ( I like the medium (hot) but my normally-medium friends usually can't eat the food because it's too hot.) The atmosphere is nice I like the white table cloths, soothing lighting, etc.
author: Amanda A.

description:
Waste of money.

Take it from me, I know good Indian food, this is not the place to go.  I couldn't believe it was as crowded as it was for such subpar/borderline bad food. You can make Indian better than this place. The curries were so watered down and the chicken tikka masala lacked any kind of flavor. However, it certainly didn't lack cream!  The appetizer was the one highlight (samosa). So if you go, get these and head right back out. It's not worth wasting your money.
author: A V.

description: Hate.  They gave me (a vegetarian who ordered from the vegetarian section of the menu) chicken when I ordered paneer.  It was takeout, and I didn't know until I got all the way home...and bit into the chicken.  I looked at the receipt, and it said paneer.  Disgusted. Will never go back.
author: M J.

description: Very disappointing dinner.  We ordered chicken tikka, mushroom-peas and aloo-gobi.   All the dishes were watery.  The mushroom-peas was plain awful - clearly they defrosted frozen peas, sauteed half heartedly with cheap mushrooms and added a hodge podge of spices.  Good aloo-gobi should be dry and flavorful, and soft without being mushy.  This dish was watery and the potatoes were not fully cooked. We also ordered a salt lassi that was completely flavorless - just watered down yoghurt with no seasonings (mustard or roasted cumin or curry leaves.)
author: Vikram P.

description: Amazing food! A little pricey but it's totally worth it-- great atmosphere.  Sometimes a long wait but you never see a long line to eat at bad places!! Perfect date spot, too.
author: Evan R.

description: I have to agree with Nish, this place is fine but not all that, and certainly not with a bag of chips.  It was a long wait for alright food.
author: Deb T.

description: This was my first real Indian food experience and boy did I love it! The sauces were tasty and the service was superb. I cannot wait to return for some more prawn korma. mmmm. My mouth is watering as I write this.
author: jodi v.

description:
I live just a few blocks away, I ate there frequently for over 10 yrs., and thought the food & service were usually very good, if not wonderful. I took many people there over the years, had many good meals as well as recommended it to lots of people.  However, I haven't eaten at Indian Oven in well over a year or 2, because it simply is not what it use to be. 
Primarily, I was very disappointed with the saag paneer on 2-3 occasions, as well as other dishes including the rice, and that finally did it. -- On each occasion I let them know the spinach was over-cooked and watery, basically tasteless but they only apologized, didn't take it off the bill or anything to compensate for it. 
As far I know, it hasn't improved, given these other reviews. I'm sorry to say I would not go back unless I was told it had changed ownership or had actually improved significantly. I hope they are reading these reviews and taking heed, as I would love to able to eat there again. Anyone know of a excellent Indian restaurant other than Dosa and one that serves good saag paneer?
author: Catherine A.

description: Had a lovely dinner with Miriam W. at Indian Oven in Jan 2006 (the Chilean seabass tikka masala was so good, as was the aloo gobi saag [spinach, cauliflower, and potato]). Have been here a few times. I also like their vegetable pakoras, bhindi masala (love okra!), saag mushroom, garlic naan, kheer, and the mango juice. Can be a little cramped inside. Oh, the curries are good too!
author: Hao L.

description:
um, what happened to this place? either it used to be waaaay better or my indian food eating skills have appreciated over the past few years. some friends and i ordered take-out from here the other nite to munch on while watched the pres debate. everything was pretty bad. i don't understand how you can be an indian restaurant and screw up garlic naan. how is that even possible? it was limp and chewy in a day old stale way. bleh.
