and the chicken korma was pathetic also. this is typically one of my favorite indian dishes for its sweet nuttiness.  this sauce was an unnatural color and not as creamy good as it should have been. we also ordered the okra, which altho well cooked (not slimy at all) was swimming in this boring tomato sauce with a bunch of limp onions and peppers. and where the hell did the spice go? did they just give up cause only white people eat here? lame. 

we got some lamb dish also which was passable, but still lacked any zing. it just made my tastebuds sad sad sad. 

and it was $60 for 4 of us to eat. it should have been $30. i'm done with this place. there's another indian spot right around the corner and it's loads better. go there and save yourself some cash and a mouthful of disappointment.
author: rachel p.

description: Wow.  have the lamb with yogurt and cashew sauce.  BE AMAZED.
author: Moi S.

description: Very good Indian cuisine.  I act like I know what exactly is meant by Indian cuisine, but I don't.  I just know this place serves good food.
author: Andrew R.

description: I've never had a bad meal here!  The service can be a bit flighty, but the food is wonderful...they do wonders with lamb, and anything from the tandoori oven is amazing as well.  I'll have to try Raja next...so I can comment on the little rivalry we have going on here:)
author: Sarah D.

description: My favorite indian place in SF, 4.5 stars in my book. I don't like spice so take my rating with a grain of salt. Only thing that bugs me is that its slightly more expensive than other indian restaurants. But there aren't any truly cheap Indian places so it's not a big deal to me.
author: BeeryMcGymrat X.

description: It was very good, I enjoyed all of the food and its right around the corner from Toronado.
author: Benjamin R.

description: The SEA BASS is REALLY, REALLY GOOD! If you see anything with sea bass, just order it. Otherwise India Oven pisses me off and I won't go there again most likely. One time I got to go and the guy disappeared with my 7 dollars change. He didn't apologize at all and acted like I was being low class or something. It is funny that I shrugged it off when it happened like a mature adult, but now that I'm writing and thinking about it, I would like to kick that guys ass! Also the rice is screwed up often(sooo basic people!) and though some dishes are good, it is just too much money for me to go there and not be satisfied with even one thing. 2 AND A HALF STARS.
author: Boxxxman J.

description:
i came here for dinner last night, and i thought it was pretty good.  we started off w/ a mango lassi and a glass of the sula shiraz, which is a wine made by an indo-american engineer who went back to start a vineyard in india.

for starters, we had the samosas which were huge, tasty, and came w/ 3 different dipping sauces and pickles.  for entrees, we had the aloo gobi, raita, mattar paneer, garlic naan, and the chapati.  it was my first time trying chapati, which is a whole wheat bread, which was nice and chewy.  this was a ton of food and way more than we could finish.  i am usually not a paneer fan, but the mattar paneer was really good and in a great curry sauce.  the aloo gobi is different from the ones i have had in the past and was cooked more in a tomato sauce than in a curry sauce.
author: Helen T.

description: Went here with friends who said it was good. We were a bit skeptical given all the negative Yelp reviews. We had low expectations but were very pleasantly surprised. Started with chicken and veggie pakoras. The chicken was better, but both were very tasty. Wife had aloo gobi and it was great. I had chicken vindaloo and it may have been the best I've ever had. Ordered extra spicy, and it was, but not just crazy hot. It was full of rich complex flavors and it was really great. Service was a bit on the slow side, and the waiters mumbled a bit, which made it hard to hear in a crowded and sometimes loud restaurant, so I deducted one star for that. But overall, this is definitely one of the best Indian places we've found in the bay area, and we'll be back.
author: Quentin V.

description:
paid 80$=got sick. muscle cramps, difficulty breathing...
everything looked fresh though. 
their masala sauce isn't as good as pakwan.
never again with indian oven,
i'll stick with $25 at pakwan.
author: schitzen h.

description: The food is fine.  Nothing outrageous or delightful or really that exciting.  The location is nice, the ambiance is defiantly a step up from say your naan n curry... and you won't wreak of curry days later... but.  well.  the food just isn't as good as it seems like it should be.  it is fine.  really.  but if you are looking for something really destination worthy... keep looking.
author: Samantha W.

description: Favorite Indian restaurant period.  Everything is delicious and the staff are wonderful.  Sometimes the wait is excessive but it's always worth it.
author: Dana C.

description:
Probably the nicest Indian place i've been to in the city. I guess after going to dozen of places that are hole-in-the-wall, a white tablecloth place seems a little odd to me. Well my former boss insisted it was the best in the city, so I figured why not check it out. I rarely get aggravated by poor service or crowds at a restaurants but this place was sure pushing it. I was there for dinner on a Saturday night (ya shoulda known better) the place was packed and it took 45 min to finally get seated. Once inside it was very crowded and overly formal, again unusual for Indian places i've been to in the city. Again forgetting that I was in a "classy" establishment I start looking around for the free chai... none to be found. Bummer but again to be expected. The other thing that irked me was our waiter not so subtly forced us to get rice along with our dishes. Ya... The food however was good, Tikka Masala was tender and a vegetable dish pretty tasty.  Go there if you want Indian but are in need to a somewhat formal atmosphere, otherwise stay away. 

PS. Its on Haight and Fillmore, it isnt the tenderloin, but since it tries to be a nicer place, take a cab or drive.
author: Chris F.

description: A consistently good Indian place--just about every item on the menu is strong, the setup is nice, and the service, at least in my experience, has been pleasant.  Not the best Indian restaurant in SF, but definitely one that I make it a point of visiting from time to time.
author: Ty D.

description: SImply my favorite Indian restaurant in San Francisco.  Best saag paneer EVER!  Try the chicken tikki masala, also wonderful.  The fish tandori is also one of my favorite dishes, very tender tasty bass!  The prices are reasonable for the quality of food and service.  I live in the Lower Haight, so I'm here at least once a week!
author: Jeff S.

description: Came here last night on a recommendation.  The fish and spinach combination was excellent--the fish was not dried out at all and we scraped it up.  We also ordered two naans--the onion and garlic one was fine but the one with the goat cheese was too not.  The texture didn't go well with the naan.  Would come back here again and try other dishes.
author: Nancy H.

description: Is as good as it gets. Parking difficult. Orange sherbet okay.
author: Yan Biao B.

description: Mediocre. I used to work in the south bay, and for the price, this doesn't compare to places like Amber in Mtn. View.  This place is way overhyped.  We had the Navratan Korma which was pretty good, but the Chicken Tikka Masala was way too salty.  Spice was perfect, decor is nice, but its way overpriced.
author: Larissa W.

description: Really good food. Been there just once, but I liked the fish curry and the okra I had.
author: Anish K.

description: pretty good indian food, a little on the pricey side, but generally worth it.
author: Michael E.

description: It's just a'ight Indian food here.  It's definitely priced like it's the next best thing to the Taj Mahal though.  They cram people in like the streets of Delhi and make scores of others (the lepers) wait outside for days for a free table.  I would rather go to the Tenderloin for some cheap and good Indian or the other places that don't make me wait forever.  I guess it's a good place to take picky people who don't want to deal with the Tenderloin.
author: Jill D.

description: Beautiful, intimate ambiance. Kitchen area is out in the open, which is cool. Everything tasted very fresh and homemade. The prices were reasonable too.
author: L M.

description: The two good things about my meal at Indian Oven were the Chai and the service. The food was really quite disappointing. We ordered Chicken Biryani and Rogan Josh and both turned out off the mark. The rice in the Chicken Biryani tasted soggy and overly 'curried' and the lamb seemed to be missing some key ingredient like salt or garlic. I've had much better Indian in the city in other places and don't recommend this restaurant.
author: D. S.

description: I am a big fan of the halibut dish. Unfortunately, one dish doesn't justify waiting in the long line. Overall it's decent food with relatively good service but very crowded.
author: Phil M.

description: Nice, competent Indian food. A dependable place for a good meal. Not the best food in the city, and a bit expensive considering some of the other Indian joints, but the atmosphere is pretty classy, and it's in a pretty good location. If you want Indian food, but aren't willing to go over to the tenderloin, you might try here.
author: Dana L.

description: We eat here or order out about once every week or two. In comparison to the tandoorloin joints, your extra few bucks gets you higher quality, more consistency, and a pleasant atmosphere and waitstaff. You could take a date here. Personally I've zeroed in on the saag and curry dishes as my favorites. Have had rather dry tandoor and some plain veggie dishes and biryani, but I'm totally addicted to the more flavorful dishes. The quality and taste is usually several steps above what you get around the corner, not to mention environment and service. Not the best indian on the entire planet, but one of my favorites.
author: Tom L.

description: I don't see the appeal. There aren't rats running around, and its got fancy white table cloths, but we come here for the food, right? The food is just OK. So, I find it overpriced and not as flavorful as I like my Indian food. Some of the other comments corroborate my experience.  It's not worth it, especially if you happen to arrive on a crowded night and you sit in the back, upstairs room. I felt like I was stuck in the corner in detention while the cool kids get a room with windows...
author: Kat T.

description: We had dinner there on a Saturday. They were quite busy. We were promptly seated. But the waiter (manager or owner?) came 15 minutes later AFTER he took order from the diners seated next to us who came in 15 to 20 minutes AFTER us. Their drinks and food arrived BEFORE we were served our drinks. Clearly the servers could not be bother when we mentioned to him. The place was extremely noisy The food which arrived 30 to 40 minutes after our appetizers, was decent. We have had much better Indian food in London, for example. All in all it was not a pleasant outing. We would never come back.
author: Roland D.

description: this place was awesome!!!  we had a good variety of dishes and they all were great.  i couldn't stop eating it.
author: Jody P.

description: Deliriously delicious food!  The lamb is cooked to perfection and literally melts in your mouth ... Come in whatever mood you are and leave in a dreamy state of mind!  But come early or make reservations - the line can be long ... However, it's worth the wait!
author: Sabine W.

description: I was upset with the portions and the quality of the food for the cost. I wouldn't recommend this place.
author: Nathaniel G.

description:
I really like this place (have eaten here for almost 10 years) -- friendly service, tasty food, wide selection.  Indian Oven has been and continues to be a San Francisco institution.  Two challenges with Indian Oven: the location can sometimes be a bit skeezy, and parking is a real pain in the *ss.

On occasion, when craving Indian Oven food, I've had to double-park (my apologies to all of you), call ahead, and get their food to go.  Just as tasty but I had to do the clean-up...
author: Joe S.

description: friends lived up the block, went here a lot, never had a bad meal....
author: Joe O.

description:
Went there early enough (5:15pm) so I didn't encounter the kind of the line around the block which some reviewers mentioned.

The food is good, but not that special.  At these prices, I would have expected something more special.  The portions are average, and the spices didn't have the life it should have.  However, it serves some interesting wines from India, and the $15 bottle of Sula sparkling wine was pleasant enough.

Not living in the area, I wouldn't go some distance to go here, but if it's close, and know what to expect, it's far from the worst choice you could make.
author: Anonymous M.

description: SO GOOD. Best Indian food I've found this close to my house. A little pricey for me but it's great. So down.
author: Bethany D.

description: Awesome food and wonderful space.  But the quality isn't as good as was say in 1990's-- I hope they fix it or they will lose it.
author: Princess P.

description: This place has been consistently busy for years. I think it's one of the nicer decent Indian restaurants in the city however I'd much rather go around the corner to Naan N' Chutney, which has better flavors, cheap and BYOB.
author: Sara W.

description: Indian Oven is a fairly decent Lower Haight eatery that is best enjoyed in the quiet back room, which can accommodate large groups for dinner. Slightly on the pricey side, the food is reasonably tasty but not memorable. If you're walking by and the lineup outside is a long one (which is common), I'd keep on walking down to Haight and Webster for Rotee. Better prices, better food, and more appealing vibe. Somehow, Indian Oven just doesn't come together. It isn't nearly as enjoyable as its upscale vibe wants it to be. As a customer, you're kind of left wanting something more from the dining experience.
author: Marc S.

description:
very mediocre and over-priced.

used to love this place, but last night I went and NOTHING was good except the service.  

All the food was just acceptable (I considered sending the Vindaloo back, but the waiter brought me hot sauce trying to fix it, so that got an extra star).

I'll never go back
author: Java Z.

description:
I'd been meaning to try this place forever, finally went there. Like Thep Phanom down the street, it seemed to win "Best Of" awards for years.  

But, as is the case with Thai food, until the advent of the Tandoor-Loin holes-in-the-wall, SF was pretty much devoid of decent Indian food.  That means this place was winning rave reviews from people who didn't know any better.

Well the food sucked.  All the dishes were watery, flavorless.  And it's not inexpensive.  I couldn't believe how far below my expectations it turned out to be.
author: Ritch G.

description: Yummy Indian food! One of the best in my opinion. It's popular so call ahead.
author: Stephanie I.

description: Love the lamb and the pratha. I haven't had food this consistently great in a long time. It's on my list of once a monthers for sure. The only suckish thing is how many tables they cram in. Your literally on top of the other patrons and it's like musical chairs to get to the bathroom. I order take out, so still 4 stars from me.
author: Chris S.

description: I like the decor of this restaurant - I'm not sure, but it the space looks like a converted Victorian.  The food is good, the beer is very cold, and the service is OK.  My group had some trouble with waitstaff responsiveness, but everything works out.  I'm told that ordering Chicken Korma sends out largely the same signal as strolling down Castro in nothing but a cod-piece.
author: Joe R.

description: Have only been once, but every item was exceptional. Friends who have gone say it is the best Indian around. Not sure about that, but darned good all the same.
author: Eric P.

description: Always hits the spot... I think Raja has them beat on a few dishes (especially butter chicken), but much better atmosphere here.  A lot of people are bullish on the Naan and Curry scene too, but I don't understand why the smell of dishwater is appealing to them.  Obviously they haven't discovered the Oven or Raja, both of which are always clean and have top notch service.
author: Todd J.

description: Food was ok, but rather uninteresting and not fantastic value. Naan and Curry beats it hands down (though ambience may not be to everyone's tastes)
author: Stuart J.

description: I really like this place a lot. I didn't realize how ungood Naan n' Chutney was ( around the corner) until I went here. Sure it is a little more expensive but the food is much better. Another case of - you get what you pay for. Spicy!
author: kristen l.

description: Consistently good.  Never had a bad meal.  But it's too spendy for not being spectacular.  And the wait is always crazy long.  Even for take-out.  They do make the best navratan korma I have ever had.  But there's better  in SF.
author: darla s.

description: Food is great with wonderful spices, but the naan is often disappointing - too thin, overdone, oily
author: Don H.

description: Indian Oven's "hot, please!" potato curry has been known to transport me into a zone beyond space and time.  Who knew that green chilis can stop the universe?   I love it.  I can't speak for the meat dishes, but I've enjoyed their veggie options, and they do a damn good samosa.
author: Olivia G.

description: Indian Oven is at the top of the list for casual upscale ethnic cuisine. Dishes are consistent and good if Westernized Indian food is your thing. It's fairly busy most evenings, but the line is always short -- just write your name down by the door. The saag paneer is always a great choice, yet skip plain naan and order the garlic.
author: Philip M.

description: Pretty darn good Indian food. I highly recommended the fish tandoori. The sea bass was light, fresh and flavorful! My other favorite was the eggplant. It was spicy and delicious with my naan. Speaking of the naan, we had the goat cheese naan. My very first bite was yummy.. but after a while, it became a little too overpowering and it started taking away the flavors from the curries. We had a lamb curry with peas and potatoes. I enjoyed that a lot as well..
author: Denise L.

description: A little bland for Indian food. Tip for vegetarians: get the lentil soup and garlic naan.
author: Jasmine T.

description: Favorite Indian in San Francisco thus far.  The Tikka Masala was perfectly spiced and a great consistency.  Samosas and naan were also perfect.
author: Susannah R.

description: Yum ~ I love this place!  I went to Indian Oven with a friend and ordered the Saag Paneer and the Chicken Tikka Masala.  Both dishes were awesomely flavored and cooked to perfection.  We sat in the room upstairs which was a bit removed from the commotion of the crowd downstairs.  Our waiter was attentive, but not obtrusive.  I'll be back!
author: Matt P.

description:
Everything I just had was off by several degrees.  

(I know this is going to make me sound like an ass, but I wish I could filter reviews on yelp by 'authors of indian origin').

The 'dal soup' (?!) was very, very thin, and had green onions, which seemed out of place.  It didn't at all have the full flavor of dal.

The mushroom mattar had plain old gray/white mushrooms, not button mushrooms, which I much prefer in desi food. it just didn't work.  I ordered 'hot,' but it seems that all the extreme-capsaicin freaks in the area have lifted the bar -- this 'hot' is somewhere between medium and mild.

The raita follows the recipe that everyone knows.  1. beat yogurt 2. grate cucumbers 3. spice it up and mix.   At these prices, I would like to eat food from a chef who has own way of doing things.

My take-out order was ready in twenty minutes, which I find more than a little suspect.  Nothing was close to hot (temperature-wise) when I picked it up.

Boo.  As a newcomer to this city, I'm surprised at how poor the choices are for food from the subcontinent.
author: Srikanth S.

description: One of my favorite Indian restaurants in the city. It is indeed a bit pricey, but for the quality of the food and service, I think its about right. I always get the saag paneer and chicken korma or the vindaloo. The rice is light and fluffy, and I usually don't pay much attention to rice, but it's quite good. The wife and I usually split samosas or some sort of appetizer too, and they're always good. Not the most amazing Indian food I've ever had overall, but certainly worthy of praise--though for some reason the food seemed a lot tastier when I lived in the neighborhood--I must be easily swayed by convenience.
author: Nat H.

description: The calamari is REALLY good, I totally recommend it. I remember having it a couple of years ago and being really impressed. They have good naan and especially yummy curries. Samosas are good too. And I subtract a star because it is a little over-priced. But for quality comes a price so I accept it!
author: Gina R.

description: Go early. It's good, real good, most of the time. But if you have to wait a long time, you start thinking it better be damn freaking good, and it's only damn good. So do what I do: start freelancing. Then you can stroll the neighborhood around 4:30 and be the first one in the door at 5:00 and relax and enjoy the (only slightly over-rated) food and the more relaxed service. Plus you don't have a boss, which is unrelated to the restaurant but quite pleasant indeed.
author: Tim B.

description: I haven't been disappointed by this place yet. The service is great, but the food is what really shines. Probably the best Indian food I've had in the city. One can tell that they use quality ingredients.
author: Kimi W.

description: Indian Oven is one of the better Indian restaurants in the city.  The chicken tikka masala is the best I've had in the city so far, but the portion is small so I usually get some extra rice and naan to soak up the sauce which is really good.  I am not a huge eggplant fan in general, but the the bengan bartha consisting of sauteed eggplant, garlic, ginger, onion, and spices is also great.
author: Josh K.

description: Yummy Naan bread.  Was sad we didn't try out the Raita and thought the portions might be a little bigger, but I tell you one thing, every single bite was amazing.  Even if you are new to Indian food, you can't go wrong here.  Excellent service, clean and upscale atmosphere.
author: Andrea R.

description:
it's not the best indian food i've ever had, but it is is the best indian restaurant i've found so far in san francisco! mmm...i've tried 3 different dishes and they've all been tastey! 

it is a little on the pricey side but worth it! i read other reviews that make it sound crazy expensive...buuut, if you're trying to spend less money then just get take away...make you're own rice...enjoy with trader joes garlic naan and a bottle of cheap wine. and that way you can watch the dark crystal at home while you eat it too ha.
author: Jennifer Z.

description: I didn't get a good sense of the Indian restaurants in SF but wasn't blown away by this highly-touted spot.  I tried their lamb briyani, chicken tikki masala, a spinach dish, garlic naan, and a lamb in a cheesy/creamy sauce.  Everything was fine. The prices were above average but still reasonable.   If you dig Indian food, it's worth a visit.
author: David L.

description:
NO STARS!!!!!  Sadly I can't post this w/o marking one..... so grudgingly, one star

Four of us ate there last night ( 9/11/11) and it was a horrendous experience.  We had 3 appetizers:  Samosas, Chicken Pakora, Squid Pakora.  The Pakoras were almost tasteless as they hadn't been salted right out of the frier.  The samosa filling was mush... mashed potato-like.
We ordered 2 Chicken dishes... we had to ask 3 times for the second one, and they were bland.  The Boti Kabob was so tough no one could chew it and it was salty.  The Allou Gobi was watery, the Paneer was kind of like broken Tofu and bland, the Sag and and dal was bland. The Pilou was, well, rice with a few peas on top. The desserts were ok.  The service was either non existent or overpowering.  Waiters could not understand what was being asked of them. So 3 appetizers, 5 Main courses w/ rice, 4 desserts, 2 lassi, and 1 Chai.  The drinks were satisfactory. The meal cost us $175.00 before tip. I was shocked when I saw the bill. The Pilou was $12... imagine $12 for a dish of rice!   I couldn't believe it... we had no alcohol and the Bill was $175 before tip.
author: EDWARD S.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by how yummy this place was. I was dubious about it, but when we went there on a recent Friday night, the place was hopping, and for good reason. The food was yummy, the prices right, and the service fast. This is by far my favorite Indian spot in the nabe.
author: Melissa J.

description: Good food, nice atmosphere and good service.  Both the saag paneer and paneer tikka korma were great!
author: Erika F.

description: it is just awesome. this restaurant is the best indian restaurant ive ever been. curry, naan, tandoori chicken... everything is good. not only food, but atmosphere is gorgeous. my image of an indian restaurant was not very classy (dont get me wrong, maybe because i didnt went good indian restaurants) so im little bit surprised when i arrived here. my review is somewhat biased because my friends work there but at least i spent great time there.
author: Sho Y.

description: The food is good, I liked the chicken tandoori the best. It's a little pricey and you don't get big portions. Service was friendly and prompt. You wouldn't be dissapointed if you ate here, but I think there are better Indian food restaurants in the city.
author: Steve S.

description: $20 = calamari curry with lots of sauce + burnt garlic naan. I wouldn't have been so bitter about my purchase if it wasn't a pick-up order and I didn't find out til later that my naan was burnt. Aside from that, the curry was okay not spectacular, but after adding the three chutneys to it it was delicious. The staff was great; I just wish their food was too.
author: Selina L.

description: zagat says it;s the best indian in SF . . . must be pretty close. A little on the expensive side for indian, but well worth it. Tandoori mixed grill is to die for.
author: Carlos C.

description: A great Indian restaurant if you are looking for something a little more upscale.  I am partial to the Vegetable Biryani, but there are a lot of awesome dishes on the menu.  The wait can be long and it is mostly outside because there is no waiting area, so be sure to make a reservation.
author: Joanna S.

description: Yummy. We got the chicken tikka masala, vindaloo, and a lamb dish- and different na'ans. It was very scrumptious. Clean, nice staff, and the only issue really is parking. It's neat to get some good Indian cuisine without enduring the squalid conditions of a ghetto. And they are even in a rough neighborhood. Went there about ten years ago and it was equally yum then.
author: Anna B.

description: This was a solid pick for a big group of us. The diehard indian food fans weren't blown away but weren't disgusted either. Those who were a little on the fence about Indian could do well here, and the aesthetic of the place was really nice. I'd go back, but would try and customize and get things a little less americanized next time.
author: Greycella L.

description: Definitely one of the places I take my out of town friends...this place is soooo freaking good.  Their nhan is amazing, the garlic nhan has huge pieces of garlic in them, their veg dishes are extremely flavorful and taste like the authentic dishes my indian friends' moms have made for me in the past.  i've been here so many times and have never had a bad experience with the staff or the food.  yes, there is a wait but it's worth it and if you hate it that much, try going on a weekday night or earlier.  get there early, grab some coffee, grab a drink or go across the street to Upper Playground art gallery.  i've tried chutney in the loin and shalamars and viiks and a handful of other places...indian oven is my favorite places by far!
author: Janet K.

description:
just ate here again -- last visit was easily a few years ago.

the food was tasty, and the portions are large, but somehow it just doesn't feel worth the price.  

fallopian swim team got it right (http://www.yelp.com/writeareview/biz/q5kFOIAk773IjoAcWJ-6sw)... and i guess this american palette just doesn't dig it as much as the cheaper pakistani options in the mission.  (not to mention i was totally spoiled living near 6th street in nyc for several years -- now that's some damn tasty and CHEAP indian food!)
author: hillary h.

description:
Top notch food.  
There is a reason this place is always jammed.
Great tikka masala, vindaloo, saag, korma and sides.  

Only wish they delivered and/or had a location in the Upper Haight.
author: WP D.

description: Of the four Indian restaurants I've tried in the city, Indian Oven is hands down the best one.   I think that they are pretty consistent too, even when busy.  Two of the times I went there they were SLAMMED and yet the food didn't suffer...very hard to do if you've ever worked in a kitchen or seen an episode of Kitchen Nightmares! :)  The flavors are always on point and the dishes are wonderful to share. I enjoy taking people that have never eaten Indian food here because it wins over even the most skepital foodies in my flock.  The naan is great, the quality of their meat is high and I think they have the tasiest Korma I've ever tried.  Service and ambiance are good but parking is a bitch, but where isnt it?
author: J L.

description: Just okay. We ordered the Paneer Tikka Masala (vegetarian), chicken tikka masala, and some vegetable curry dish - and all three sauces were really runny and that flavorful- which I don't like. Also, the Naan is pretty flat and again, just okay - nothing to get excited about. Service was okay, For the price I would not go there again, especially since Rotee is one block away www.roteesf.com. The ambiance is the only part I like about India Oven but if you're going for food taste and quality I'd pass on this place.
author: Erin S.

description: Indian Oven definitely serves some of the better Indian/Pakistani food I have had in SF, and I do think that they continually produce dishes of a much higher quality than their competition in bordering neighborhoods.  During my most recent visit, our group had a number of dishes that everyone enjoyed enough to eat the plates clean.  We had one mixed seafood dish(cant remember the name) that was excellent, and surely the group favorite.  While the extra quality/ambiance is certainly apparent in the prices, I would be much more likely to take my parents here than oher Indian/Pakistani restaurants I have visited in SF.
author: Morgen N.

description: GREAT, creative Indian food.  Very sweet servers.  They overheard a few people in our group saying happy birthday to me and brought out a dessert dish with a candle (no one told them)!!  I have no problem bringing friends here -- it's always reliable.
author: crystel s.

description: This place is fantastic, although downstairs can be a little crowded and loud.  Request an upstairs table and then get whatever appeals to you on the menu - it's all very good!
author: Bob C.

description: I have always said this is the best Indian restaurant in the city but having worked with a few Brits who know their Indian food. I've revised it to the best NORTHERN Indian restaurant in the city. Whatever the case, it's damn good. It's high quality - i.e. I'd eat fish here but not at many other Indian joints. I've never had anything I didn't love - samosas, tandoori, tikka, korma, et al. I must mention that my wife and I THINK we got food poisoning here a few months back but I honestly believe that was a freak incident. It doesn't deter us. We still eat here a lot.
author: Bill R.

description: I like the vibe here as much as the food.  Indian Oven attracts a cool crowd for its reliable Indian food. Warm, convivial, inviting and in the Lower Haight stretch of Fillmore, the tables were crowded when we arrived on a recent Friday evening. However, one of the servers was quick to say he'd take care of us and made good on his promise of having to wait no more than 10 minutes. Good samosa, decent saag and authentic chutney selections last weekend got me on the track toward an upcoming return to India, albeit this is Northern Indian cuisine.  So no dosas in house, but great naan. The mango lassi my dining companion ordered was  yummy, and the tandoori meats on adjacent tables looked great though we were eating veg on my most recent visit. Waits are to be expected, so  I recommend dining on the early or late side of peak dinner hours.
author: Deborah C.

description: Just went here last night and was disappointed.  This place used to be great but not anymore.  I gave it two stars, one for the Taj Mahal beer and one for the samosas.
author: Sarah N.

description: The rice was dry, the main dish was watery, the seating was cramped and it definitely won't satisfy a curry craving. However, despite all this, the food was super delicious. Definitely recommended if you're looking for delicately flavoured, contemporary Indian dining.
author: Glen M.

description:
i love it all!! but my favorite is anything with lamb. their lamb is soooo tender and succulent, i could drool just thinking about it. 

if you can, sit upstairs.
author: eve l.

description: Altough it is small and your right up agains t the table next to you. This place is really good. A bit pricy 3 entrees 2 orders of garlic nann and a soda roughly $60 but worth it. There was no wait when I went sunday around 7pm, but at about 7:30pm a line started to form.
author: sarah s.

description: For a while I'd been complaining that I hadn't yet found great Indian Food in SF.  I guess I just wasn't looking, because a few blocks from my house is Indian Oven.  We went here on a Friday night, and waited about 20 minutes, but it was worth it.  The food is incredible!  Samosas melted in our mouths, and the garlic naan was a perfect accompaniment to the Dal Sag and Navratan Korma.  Lots of good vegetarian choices.
author: Shelley G.

description: love this place. the food is delicious and the quality is always consistently excellent. i highly recommend everything on the menu without exception. its that good!
author: alisa o.

description: This place has an upstairs dining area that is more spacious. The food is good and they also have a decent wine list which is unusual at most Indian restaurants. We had assorted appetizer, paneer makhani, saag paneer and bread basket. Everything tasted good but I wish it was spicier. It's busy on Friday nights, so reservation is recommended.
author: Maya G.

description: The food was good, but living in the NW near Microsoft has spoiled me in terms on Indian food. Most of the dishes were certainly tasty, but the only thing I thought stood out were the dosas. Dosas are cheating though, as *all fried food is amazing*. Still a tasty meal, but for the price I expect a little more.
author: Justin V.

description: Food was excellent and lived up to it's reputation, but the service was so horrible and it was so crowded and loud the overall experience is disappointing and overrated. We went here for my boyfriend's birthday, and although half our group was already seated upstairs, when the second half of us showed up we weren't even greated and we waited in their non-waiting area getting dirty looks from the other customers waiting, and strange looks from the wait staff. we finally had to call our own friends and march through the restaurant to find the table on our own. I'll probably never go back here.
author: Amy P.

description: It is the best Indian food in the city. My friend who is Indian told me that I must venture to this place to taste what real Indian food is like and so I succumbed to the challenge. As I entered the small but quant restaurant I fell in love with the staff. They were so helpful with my order. I wanted a dish that was not a traditional order from most patrons. I was excited and when I was brought my dish I moaned with every bite. Even the leftovers were that delicious.  Anything on the menu is worth trying!
author: M C.

description: I think I will go back before I decide if I love it, or think it's boring. We started with Garlic naan and samosas. I agree with other reviews that the naan was a bit thin and dry, but had the perfect amount of garlic. The samosas were tasty, especially when I added chutney. I thought all 4 condiment sauces were the best I've ever had. Then we shared tandoori chicken, aloo ghobi, and saag aloo. I would go back for the tandoori chicken, because it was perfectly spiced. As for the saag aloo, it was much lighter, and had less liquid that I expected, but I figured it was because they didn't douse it in cream. I'm still not sure if I liked it because it felt like it was missing something. Same with the aloo ghobi. So few ingredients that you can taste each one, but I feel like they didn't come together as a whole. Also, I think I like Indian when it's crowded, noisy, and darker. It seemed weird to have white tablecloths.
author: Merrilee T.

description: Best service, and most flavorful indian restaurant around.  Always crowded, but still pumps out exceptional food.
author: andria p.

description: Not much to say about the Indian Oven except that if you even subtly like Indian food you can't go wrong here. The atmosphere, service, and food has been consistently good over the past ten years. Can get a little crowded but the wait is usually quick if you go early in the week. I've been to other places that are as good but not nearly as refined.
author: H K.

description:
Lamb - any dish we ordered with lamb - was good. I liked the garlic naan. I found the food more to my liking when we ordered it spicy.

Sure, I may not know exactly what authentic Indian food is like and I have not been to all the other places mentioned in some of the reviews for comparison but we enjoyed their food and atmosphere.

Make sure to get there before 6pm.
author: Keisuke O.

description:
Indian Oven is the best indian food in the city, hands down.  The spices taste very fresh.  The bread is perfectly flaky and doughy.  I recommend the chichen korma which is so creamy.  

Prices are on the higher side and they don't deliver but they do take-out.  The food and staff are amazing.
author: Ben S.

description:
This place used to be good but NOT ANYMORE!  To be honest it didn't really taste like Indian food. The spicing was off. We ordered a fish curry where the "curry" tasted like canned soup.
The Dal soup was inedible and the vegetable Biryani was more like a spanish rice. To be honest, there were no Indians working there and I wonder about the level of knowledge about Indian food. Way overpriced and disappointing.
author: Julie N.

description: One of the best price / quality indian places in SF! Everything fits, fantastic food, premium beer brands, premium interior (one of the few indian restaurant with white table linen), great atmosphere, and not too expensive. Good place for a first date.
author: kris k.

description: This is the best Indian food in the city.  Try to make a reservation or get there before 7:30PM so you don't have to wait.
author: Bethany L.

description: Great Indian food, always busy but worth the wait. If I lived closer I'd be a regular.
author: Micah K.

description:
Best indian rest. in the city!  I love coming here~amazing food and cheap prices.  

Everything i have tried here is amazing though i feel the need to always get the paneer korma b/c it is just that good.

they have the best chai too.
author: n. h.

description: Went here with some old friends on a recent vacation, and had a nice time. The food came out quickly, and the service was friendly. The food was delicious.
author: Anthony V.

description: Very good, if not inexpensive.   Sometimes patrons have to wait.
author: The P.

description: this restaurant has some of the best Indian food I've ever had. We started out with the Gujarati kachori's and the onion bhajias. Let me add that they were made by an actual Gujarati so they WERE the actual thing! Then we went on to have the paneer mukhni, tikka masala, rogan josh, & the chicken vindaloo. They were not only spicy, but they were also flavorful and the right size. It seems as if restaurants give you such big portions that they have the doggie bag waiting by your order because they know that you're going to take it home!!! But anyway, the naans were warm and fluffy and the rice better than the average rice you get at other restaurants. It is a little expensive but you have to remember that a lot of work goes into a curry and the spices themselves aren't cheap. The only issue is parking- you have to search for it along the streets or in a parking garage which can become pricey. But in all, this restaurant is probably one of my favorites and I would definately come back again!!!
author: igy c.

description: My favorite place to eat spicy food to jump start labor.  Others in our old 'hood have done the same!
author: Meghan G.

description: I've only eaten from this restaurant as delivery and I've been very pleased each and every time. The food, including naan, tastes very fresh and always very delicious. It's a perfect medley of spice and richness deleivered to me in a very reasonable amount of time.
author: Heather P.

description: Man... I live near Lower Haight so everybody has a fix on Indian Oven near Haight and Fillmore. And I'm Indian, so every passerby has to ask what I think of their food. Even everytime I pass the damn street, there are at least 10 people standing outside as if they're in a line for free cocaine. So, eventually I decided to find one night and dive in with voluptuous apetite. It was a fine friday evening and surprisingly, there was no line. Wow..so I ordered the lentil soup, pulao and chicken korma (their speciality as I was told) ... the lentil soup was okay, but as soon as I tasted the curry - I knew something had gone wrong. Either my taste buds had gone under surgery or the food wasnt simply good. They dished out an entire can of tomato sauce over marinated chicken and served it with rice. So, I call the waiter and ask him whats wrong..he takes a sip of the curry and hauls back to the kitchen. He returns with a red scramble of curry... a bite of which drops me to the floor. This time its tomato puree mixed with red chili's - enough for entire Lower Haight to cry out loud. The rice was soggy and I left paying $30 for a half eaten dinner.  Just not worth it!
author: Sav B.

description: i am non-plussed. this is one of those weird yelp moments when you feel guilty for writing anything below 3stars becuase in general you agree with yelp taste. however, i've had indian delivery that was from "crummy" places and it was so much better and half the price. the price alone will keep me from giving it a second chance.
author: Chelsea B.

description: indian oven is the best indian food that i have had here in san francisco.  now, i'm no expert considering i have only had indian about 4 times but i thought it was really great.  we had lots of naan (try the garlic if you like garlic), assorted tandoori, samosas, chicken saag (which has spinach), and my favorite lamb biryani.  i love biryani - lots of spices and rice.  definitely try it even if you dont know if you like indian food - i think its good for first timers!!
author: Carolyn B.

description: This is the second time that i have been to this restaurant.  The first time i thought it was okay but i also had a lot of wine.  This time I had no wine and thought it was really awful.  I think all the food is frozen. The korma was very watery. My friend ordered the curry chicken, and that too was watery.  Also immediately after eating here i felt sick and had to use the bathroom!  I still feel sick today! I give this place one star for service and one star for the garlic naan which was decent. The serving staff was really nice and very helpful and fast. ..but i will not be going to this place again!
author: Julie G.

description:
Nothing divides a nation like Indian food.  I'm going to side with the Indian Oven fans here because Indian Oven is absolutely, without a doubt, my favorite Indian restaurant.  

Here's why I love Indian Oven: 
1.  People complain about the prices and, yes, the meat dishes look pricey, but their vegetarian dishes are all several dollars cheaper.  So, for people who like their veggies, a vegetarian entree at Indian Oven costs about a dollar or two more than a vegetarian entree at most of the cheap, fast-food style Indian/Pakistani places in town--which is quite a steal considering the quality at Indian Oven!
2.  Their vegetables taste fresh.  I like Indian food that tastes like it's been simmering in a giant pot all day as much as the next person, but I LOVE Indian food that tastes like it was prepared just now, specially for you.
3.  Their paneer is the best I've tasted.  It's a bit more tender than the paneer served at most other places.
4.  Service is always very friendly and not overbearing.
5.  Their spices are always perfect (in my opinion, of course).  No one spice ever overpowers the others, nor do the spices detract from the vegetables.  Every part of the dish gets an opportunity to show off.  The spice perfection is probably my favorite part of Indian Oven.  I think their samosas really showcase how carefully they handle their spices.  Try one!  Or two!
6.  I tend to use saag/palak as a measure of an Indian restaurant's worth.  Is the spinach canned?  Has it been pureed into mush?  Is the restaurant covering up the canned mush flavor with too many spices?  Really, saag paneer or aloo saag is a great way to determine whether or not an Indian restaurant cares about its food!  Indian Oven passes the saag test with flying colors.  Fresh spinach; finely chopped, but not mushy; creamy, but not too heavy; little bites of fresh ginger; delicate spices with a slight kick.  Mmmmmm.
7.  They're hip to the vegans.  You can order many vegetarian dishes and request that they're made "vegan," and they'll know what you're talking about.

People look for different things in Indian restaurants, so some folks won't much care for Indian Oven.  But for me?  Indian Oven is IT.  Maybe you'll like it, too.
author: Alyson Y.

description: The samosas were excellent. The rice was not flavorful like indian basmati rice usually is and the grains were al dente if that's even possible. The naan was small in size and probably the worst naan i have had in a while. We had the chicken vindaloo, which was watery and spicy. I like spicy but not when it's the only taste of the dish. I'm not sure why this place gets good reviews. I may have to try it again, but it's also a little pricier for your standard indian restaurant.
author: Luke F.

description: I don't know why people rave about this place so much. I don't find the indian food here that great. There are much better Indian food places in SF. I have not had everything on the menu but most of the meat curries I tried were just ok.
author: Alan O.

description: Pretty damn good and reliable. The tandouri dishes are always good.The mixed tandouri appetizer is my personal favorite. The chicken tika masala is perfect. The vegetable dishes are also good. Best kheer in town!
author: robert d.

description: I ate here twice in the last 12 months, both times it was very good, and excellent for the price.  Vegetarian dishes were ordered.  Prompt and attentive service, nice room, though it can get noisy.
author: Barry C.

description: pricier than most indian places, but worth every penny. the naan and chicken tikka masala were fabulous! and we tried their indian beer!(forget what it as called). this restaurant itself is also very nice and the crowd was great. afterwards, there are the haight/ashbury bars to go hopping to. actually it's probably best to go before...
author: Andrew T.

description: I don't remember the explicit details, but I really remember enjoying the couple of meals I've had there. I do have two complaints: (1) It is really hard to find parking in the area and (2) you always end up waiting because this restaurant is very popular.
author: Avid E.

description: Great Indian food.  However, watch out for the exploding lamb and pink hot pants chicken.
author: Brian K.

description: my favorite default indian place. when i want indian and don't want to think of where to go i come here. i don't actually know what good quality indian is compared to not so great quality indian but i'm pretty sure the saag paneer is considered good here. Mmmm i could use some naan and masala right about now.
author: Regina C.

description: I always leave this place satisfied, and I'm sure you will too if you order the chicken tandoori and the samosas...  Really don't see how someone could complain about either of the two.
author: Tim I.

description: 11/08 revision: i don't know what the hell happened in there but it sucks now. i used to eat there and be real happy and then when we ate there the other day i left real sad. bad naan, bad veggie-whatcha-callums for apps, bad navratan korma that i get all the time and was always good (tasteless and had weird chunks of...pineapple? something gross) and my husband had bad stuff too. disapPOINTed!!
author: Cristabel L.

description: love the food here. but as with most indian restaurants, service isn't the best thing. very crowded dining area. but all in all, it's all about the food here. simply flavorful and very well prepared. no pretense, just a great place to bring friends and eat in a big table. price is on the high side.
author: Raymond G.

description: I don't know if Indian Oven is the best Indian restaurant in SF, but it's pretty good.  I have to admit that my expectations were probably a bit too high since two of my friends (who are also Indian) had raved about the place quite a bit.  First, the ambiance is pretty decent.  I've almost come to expect a dingy, dark decor at an Indian restaurant, but the upstairs at Indian Oven was pretty nice.  The restaurant was well lit and clean.  The location of the bathroom was a little odd and the tables were a little close together, but other than that, I was pleasantly surprised by the physical location.  I think the place would even be OK for a date.  Now for the food... for starters, my two friends and I shared the Chicken Pakora and Tandoori Assorted.  The pakoras were pretty tough.  The chicken just didn't have a lot of taste.  I really liked the Tandoori assorted platter though.  All 3 of the different meats were very juicy and flavorful.  For entrees, we shared the Chicken Korma, Bhuna Ghost and Jheenga Masala.  The Chicken Korma was pretty good.  A lot of times the sauce can be too watery or too thick, but the consistency was just right.  Also, the chicken pieces were moist and tasty.  I was pretty disappointed by the Bhuna Ghost.  As soon as we got menus, both of my friends went straight to that dish.  However, the lamb pieces were pretty tough and fatty.  It just didn't do anything for me.  The Jheenga Masala was tasty and had a good amount of shrimp.  We also ordered some regular naan and garlic naan.  The naan was satisfactory, but nothing special.  Overall, the service was pretty good.  Our waiter was responsive and friendly.  It's a bit out of the way for me... all the way out in the Lower Haight, but I'm pretty sure I'll go back at some point when I need my Indian fix.  Being Indian, I'm pretty picky about the food my peeps serve, but was overall pretty pleased with my experience at Indian Oven.
author: Saw T.

description: good indian.  they say the oven itself is pretty wild.  it's a nice indian restaurant - or nice enough - good enough for a casual date.
author: Spencer W.

description: The food here is good but man will you pay for it. If you're looking for a place to go when your folks (hopefully they're buying) or business colleagues (yeah expense account) are in town or you need to show all your friends how much cash you carry thanks to your new raise or bonus then by all means go. The truth is there is more affordable Indian that is on par with Indian Oven's quality. Granted they have some "traditional" dishes that others don't and they throw a bone (I mean plant stem) to the vegetarian friend you might have. To be honest I have two friends who prefer this place to many others in the city, so there is no way to truly know unless you test it out yourself. Service is great. Parking takes a C- not for availability but for quality. The area may not meet with your level of urban comfort (i.e. people screaming snitch and I'll kill you because you're a cop caller). None of which may be directed at you since you will likely be a very large fly on the wall that is the Lower (and really Upper) Haight Street Social Dynamic!
author: Ryan M.

description: Honestly, I barely remember the food I tasted because I was so caught up in the dinner conversation next to me. It was a 90's looking metal dude with long butt-rock hair complete with a British accent, obviously on his first meeting with his girlfriend's parents. Yeah, I'm a nib-shit, but also our tables were practically on top of each other so I couldn't focus on anything else but their awkward night of conversation and food sharing. I think the food was okay or good or not really what I was expecting, but I can't really tell you what I had or why I liked it/disliked it. I remember being hungry even after I ate part of my boyfriend's portion, so I think that the entrees were too small (especially for the price - I do remember my bill being well over what I was wanting to pay). I think the place was trying to hard to be fancy and romantic, and I wasn't into the decorating and cheesy table adornments (I remember white tablecloths, maybe candles and/or flowers? Ew.) And I felt like my waiter was annoyed with me because I took too long to order (I hate that feeling). Overall, I think that I would much rather go to another low-key restaurant that serves better food at better prices and I'll leave this place to all you rich, trendy people.
author: Brittany L.

description:
yum yum yum.

though the last time I was there the samosas were so spicy we couldn't eat them, and we like spicy.  I don't know what happened--different cook?
One of my favorite restaurants but take MUNI because the neighborhood very difficult to park in and the people who live there get very frustrated and yell at you.
author: nona c.

description: We were a large group so we got a reservation a few days earlier. We sat in the back room, which was fine. The server didn't rush us too much - overall the service was OK. The food was decent but overpriced (small portions with mainly sauce and not much meat). I'd rather go to an Indian buffet place.
author: Alp M.

description: it is a touch pricey, and sometimes you have to wait for a bit. however there is a lovely fish dish that is worth it. everything is very scrumptious.
author: melissa h.

description: dal soup, chicken tikka masala, lamb pasanda, bengan bartha (roasted eggplant), spinach paratha, and the kheer (traditional indian rice pudding) were among the items we indulged in this evening.  this place is wonderful!  the food was so good and service was prompt and friendly.
author: Steven K.

description: i can't speak to the authenticity of indian oven's food, but i can tell you that it is damn good. make a reservation if you plan on eating there at peak hours, or do like i and the other locals do- order out for pick-up. the samosas are out of this world, the chicken tikka masala is always creamy and delish, and the dal saag is outstanding. the only inconsistency i've found is that there is definitely a "spicy chef" and a "not-so-spicy chef." i like my food spicy, so it doesn't bother me when we get the spicy chef- but if you prefer your food mild, make sure to tell them as such.
author: oona m.

description: nothing mind blowingly innovative or new here but they get high marks for both quality and consistency.  ambience rates high as well, what with the soft lighting that makes the ugly people look prettier and the pleasant din of conversations held over food never gets overpowering. i'm all about the kashmiri biryani:  rice!  fruit!  nuts!  i love all of these things!  what a holy trinity of yum.
author: beltrand a.

description: mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm Navratan Korma is the best!!!  I love this place!
author: Landy G.

description: best indian in the city, at least that i've been to. and the vindaloo has a kick.
author: Dean E.

description: even if i went veg awhile ago, that lamb pasanda is just a little confection of genius. they have nice things. that doesnt pertain to the rice. lagunitas ipa on tap (hopefully at this point they still have this). if it doesnt work for you, i apologize profusely. i think its worth a shot at least once though.
author: Christopher J.

description: Great Indian restaurant.  I've been there twice and ordered alot of different things on the menu, always satisfied without that "too full" or "too greasy" feeling that other indian places can leave you with.
author: Kristen T.

description: This used to be my FAVORITE indian place in the city. Over the past year or so, the food has become very inconsistent. I haven't had a good meal there in over 8 months. I have stopped giving it anymore chances. Not sure if the cook changed or they changed the amount or type of spices used, but the food has become overly salty.
author: K D.

description: Wow, the best Indian cuisine I've had since I moved to SF. We met some friends here, and we were all seriously impressed with the service, adequate wine list (Bogle Pinot, so not bad) and excellent dinner. White linen, which is a little more high class than your usual tikka joint. I got to see the chef demonstrate how to make naan in the kiln-like oven. My lamb was perfection, and their samosas were to die for. We've ordered takeout from here too, on nights when we couldn't get a reservation, and that has always been delicious as well.
author: Sarah Y.

description: Seabass and lamb naan was very good.  The mango lassi was yummy.  The waiters are very very nice.  Good atmosphere!
author: S. K.

description: The food is just ok.  The Vegetable Korma was good but the Chicken Tikka Masala was very very smokey tasting and not good at all.  Also the prices are on the high side for Indian food.  The worst part was that we left overs and they said they would box them up for us.  My meal was vegetarian (i do not eat meat) and my boyfriends was chicken. They put both together along with the leftover rice and naan in a plastic container that of course when it was carried out everything mushed together and we had to throw it out..........not impressive.
author: Krista F.

description: Best Indian food in the city! Period! Their curries are to die for, their tandoor dishes are amazing. perfect blend of spices for the Traditional Indian lover. For those of you who can't handle REAL INDIAN SPICY then check out the place kitty corner. Indian oven is the best when you crave that HOT Indian flavour. And if you thought that Indian oven was hot food, if the waiters there gave you what THEY thought was hot....your nose would be blinking. There is a room in the back in addition to the one up front, much bigger than it appears.
author: Unhappy C.

description: We went for a birthday party last evening.  Food was good however extremley overpriced.  The atmosphere was loud and cramped.  Service was not good; servers did not put dishes on the table but made you get it from him nor did he clear plates in front of you, leaving you handing your plate to him.  It would have been better to order and go.  I have had much better at other places in the city.
author: Robert B.

description: Best Indian food in San Francisco, hands down. Best for the price, the taste, all of it. Eating there is good, but be prepared to wait. Street parking sucks, but hell, it's lower Haight, what do you expect.
author: Eric D.

description: indeed, there is cheaper indian food around the corner but as the cliche goes:  you get what you pay for.  indian oven is great.  and after four visits, i can say that i've never had a bad experience.   plus, they will accommodate special requests, e.g., can i have paneer added to my chicken sagwalla?  sure, no problem!
author: Eric L.

description: This place is Indian food for moms.  It's probably the least spicy food I've ever had.  It's about as spicy as a cold cut combo at subway with a lot of mayonnaise.  The guys have to wear dorky vests that look like the kind the little monkey in a fez wears.  I think they hate you for it.
author: Dirk C.

description: My favorite Indian food in SF!  Great to eat there (smells delicious inside) or to take out.  I generally get a couple of mainstays - the saag paneer is especially delicious - and the try something new to mostly positive results.  The staff is friendly and numerous and team oriented - so service is good.
author: Martin F.

description: My favorite Indian place in SF (ok it helps that it's just a few blocks away from home). Pretty standard Indian dishes but they do them all very well. It gets busy, but still you can usually just walk in or wait a few minutes outside. They *will* make it spicy if you ask... I've sweated through quite a few Lamb Vindaloos there and loved every minute of it.
author: Joe F.

description: It's good... but is it really THAT good?  i don't get the rep of this eatery...i've been 5 or 6 times and never felt the atmosphere, food, or price was worth the wait.
author: Jinae L.

description: ABSOLUTELY HORRIBLE!  I went there after a friend suggested it to me and not only was the food incredibly oily, but the fish was undercooked and smelled rotten.  When we complained, the manager told us to "shut up and eat."  If you want terrible food and service, go to Indian Oven... you won't be disappointed!
author: Sid G.

description: We loved this place.  The food was fantastic and the service was very friendly.  My only suggestion would be to try and sit in the front part of the restaurant near the windows as its a little more lively opposed to sitting in the back.  Bottom line, if you're looking for high quality Indian food in the city look no further.  This is the spot.
author: Marc G.

description: We had the curried lamb and also the okra last night -- wonderful!  I also think that the staff is very good.  They're always crowded so go early if you don't want to wait.
author: laurel t.

description: i've been here a few times over the years, and it's just ok. it's a small room, always packed and hot in there. speaking of hot, if you don't like spicy, avoid at all costs. everything is spicy. even dishes that shouldn't be spicy are spicy. i was forced to get some mint chocolate cookie ice cream on the way home to put out the fire in my mouth. thanks a lot, indian oven. there's like 600 calories that i can't get back. anyhow, we had calamari which was not great; ok samosas (better down the street at naan and chutney); pakora was pretty good; and for dinner, jalfreezi (sp), chicken bharta, tandoori shrimp, and tikka masala. let me reiterate: everything was so spicy that i was crying. it was pretty good, all in all, but just too spicy for me and i actually like spicy foods. the service was pretty good, but food took a long time to arrive so be prepared to linger. i kind of think naan and chutney is better for half the price. oh, but the mango chutney and that mint green sauce was yummers. i'll probably return in like 4 years, marking my once every 4 years trend with this place.
author: Mary V.

description: i like.  the spices and level of heat they incorporate in their dishes are very well balanced - it doesn't hide anything from the main ingredients but enhances it.  the saag mushroom is a great example; this sauteed spinach and wild mushrooms dish is top.  the chicken tikka masala is great when paired with the naan - nothing new to me (after being to the gool ol dependable naan n curry), but i did appreciate the bit of fire the masala gave off.  the calamari curry is great as well.  not too sure if i recommend this place for large groups - space is limited if they seat you downstairs (there's also more room upstairs).  each dish is served good for 2-3 people max, so if you come with a group of 8 like i did (plus a baby, so 9) then you might have to order more in order to dine family style.  great ambiance, elegant and romantic, but also appropriate for small groups.  i suggest topping off your meal with their masala chai, homemade and delicious!
author: Paul A.

description: we went with a friend's recommendation and the ambience is nice but i can't say much for their curry.  we love to eat chicken mahkni but i found that it was quite watered down.  even their veggie curry was quite watered down.  i just prefer my curry more thick, i suppose.  the only thing really had me going was their assortment of bread - garlic nan, chapati and i forget.... one other kind.  eating here, i missed eating at my local indian place back in LA.
author: Ji H.
